Rutger Bregman (translated by Elizabeth Manton) argues that our societal development has stalled because nobody in politics is promoting "visionary" ideas any more, but rather simply different versions of the same basic model of society. He cites examples such as the abolition of slavery and women's suffrage as visionary ideas which were once seen as outlandish but have come to be societal norms, and suggests that few are promoting equivalent causes today.I couldn't disagree more. In the last decade, we have seen monumental changes in society and there are fierce debates about how these should be handled. The web has brought true freedom of publication, and there are fierce debates on whether fake news and abuse should be curtailed by restricting that freedom or by managing the consequences. Social media has brought a radical degree of sharing of information unseen in human history, and politicians argue non-stop about the degree to which consent to use that information should be implied or explicit. (Hello, GDPR). Voters across the Western world have expressed a strong feeling against technocracy, preferring to elect politicians on the basis of personality rather than technical skill, and there are fervent discussions about whether democracy is reaching its natural conclusion. These are all monumental debates about the very heart of society: I cannot agree with the premise that nobody is "thinking big thoughts".All of that said: I really enjoyed Bregman's book. He describes - though is explicit in saying that he is not intending to promote, whatever the press coverage may imply - three radical changes to society, namely a universal basic income, a 15-hour work week, and a world without borders. With the possible exception of the latter, I don't think any of these is actually particularly radical, which is a shame given his central thesis. He discusses each of these optimistically, drawing on evidence to suggest that each would be beneficial. He does this deftly, mixing in anecdote and data in a really engaging way, which caused me to think very carefully about these ideas. The booked helped me to look at society from a couple of new perspectives.In other words, I thought this was a great book, even though I disagreed profoundly with its central thesis.

I initially had mixed reactions as I began reading this book.....for starters I kept thinking that for a book entitled "Utopia for Realists" that it seemed pretty idealistic. I was motivated, however, to keep reading because Bregman wrote the book in a much needed effort to fix the ominously persistent problem of the ever increasing inequality in the distribution of wealth across the world. He asks the questions, "Why have we been working harder and harder since the 1980s despite being richer than ever? Why are millions of people still living in poverty when we are more than rich enough to put an end to it once and for all? And why is more than 60% of your income dependent on the country where you just happen to have been born?" The three fixes Bregman is proposing include 1) a universal basic income, 2) a shorter work week, and, 3) open borders. The bulk of the book involves providing his rational for each supported by historical information to support his thinking. Each solution is intriguing and I learned some fascinating/surprising historical facts along the way (like Richard Nixon, during his presidency, was very close to supporting a universal basic income in the U.S.). I found myself, however, wanting more specific information detailing how these would be implemented in the world in which we currently find ourselves living.Towards the end of the book Bregman tackles the issue of people's resistance to change, their limited capacity to accept new information that challenges their established mindset, and how the internet seems to make sure it feeds us mostly what we want to hear. He explains how the power of cognitive dissonance is a frightening force that keeps us from reflecting and growing. "When reality clashes with our deepest convictions, we'd rather recalibrate reality than amend our worldview. Not only that we become even more rigid in our beliefs than before". This part of the book was strikingly if not disturbingly relevant to the deep divide in thinking of people in today's political environment. I appreciated his honestly in recognizing how his own thinking can fall victim to cognitive dissonance. This is a book worth reading even if you do not believe in what he is saying.....maybe the purpose for reading it could be to challenge your own cognitive dissonance.

4.5 stars. This is a very light, accessible read for popular audiences, but i mean it as a high, remarkable compliment here.Writing for popular audiences is not an easy task, as seen by the landfill of badly written, click-baity "pop history" or "pop science"drivel you find in bookstores these days, which try too hard to be Amusing and Humorous, usually by recourse to shitting on scholars, theorists, thinkers or animals whom they don't like in what these authors imagine to be Funny prose, but is just bloated, badly edited writing. The overall effect is like eating a badly-made macaron in a pretentious, overpriced cafe. By contrast, Bregman here offers us a tightly written, engaging work that treats its subject matter, themes and topics thoughtfully and carefully. Every historical figure, theorist and thinker (even the notorious Richard Nixon) Bregman brings up is accorded care and respect. It may be a small thing, but it is something i appreciate of this writer. The ideas and evidence mustered to support his arguments are succinctly linked together, so that one comes away feeling powerfully persuaded by the writing. It has been a long time since I have read something so hopeful, so audacious, and so likable! And that's perhaps my biggest criticism with this very digestible piece - that it's so positive, so accessibly written, that skepticism almost inevitably begs itself: if things are so la-di-dah and so smooth, why hasn't Universal Basic Income, or a 15-Hour Workweek been implemented anywhere else in the world more consistently? Bregman's narrative seems to suggest that the answer is largely "accidents" and "freak missed opportunities". I would have liked if he had wrestled more seriously with some of the complexities of the historical events he brings up. As a opening salvo, a rallying cry for dreaming bigger, for grander dreams of a more equal world though, this book electrified me, admonished me for having become mired and blinkered in my small corner of the world. Highly recommended as a gateway drug into dreaming bigger, seeing further - by seeing 'backward' into the past.

Utopia. It's a subject often resigned for cynics and politicians laughing at the Left. Dystopia is much more in vogue currently. Whether we're reading it in contemporary fiction or actually living it under the rule of a talking tangerine, we don't often think about utopia and how, perhaps, it is actually viable. Something we could really make happen. Bregman, a Dutch writer, makes the case for a 'realistic utopia' in our modern world, exploring matters of economics, basic income, avoiding financial crises, man versus machine, ending poverty and eradicating homelessness, among other things. Not only does he propose solutions for what we consider societies most difficult and constant problems, but he provides real world examples of where these experiments are happening and, most importantly, succeeding. Out of all of his anecdotes, my favourite was about Ireland during the 1970s that managed to sustain their economy and even make it grow without the use of big banks. Instead, they used their local pubs as a way of creating their own currency, generating income into the millions. It seems ridiculous and possibly fictional, but it really provides a dose of reality to what we believe can only be a myth. Ultimately, he's making the case that we can make a difference and not have it break the bank. Even conservative thinkers have been brought around to this way of 'make utopia a reality' thinking- he cites Richard Nixon several times throughout the book. This is a really interesting and really digestible non-fiction piece that forces us to examine how we can solve our social problems, bypassing the government relying on opinions and beliefs, and how we can deliver actual help to those who need it. I would recommend anyone feeling disheartened by the state of the world currently to pick this book up because it will remind you that there is a way to do this and make a difference. It's not impossible.

Hayek, etc.The books starts off by recounting a lot of coincidences and unfortunate events which prevented the adoption of an unconditional basic income.In the beginning the author argues for a different look at the economy, "gross domestic product" is not a suitable measurement, but later he uses the predicted growth of the "gross worldwide product" as an argument.He talks about opening all borders as the best development aid, but only rebuts straw man arguments against the idea.I haven't counted, but he seems to use more newspaper articles than scientific papers in his arguments.Then there is a detour about "bloodletting" and randomistas.Like this review the book misses a common theme. Pretty un-rigorous and overly broad. I picked this up because I was interested in universal basic income, but this is a very shallow overview. It would be helpful to have an experienced economist's take - especially on whether they would project that UBI would cause inflation or major price increases. It seems that UBI is vulnerable to misuse, too - I can easily imagine conservative politicians funding it out of taxes on the middle and working classes, and denying UBI to undocumented people. On that note, like Bregman I support open borders, although I cannot imagine making the concessions Bregman is willing to make: "Countries [with open borders] could decide not to give immigrants the right to government assistance or not until after a minimum number of years, or not until they've paid, say, $50,000 in taxes. And you could set up similar parameters if you're concerned they form a political threat or won't integrate. You can create language and culture tests. You can withhold the right to vote. And you can send them back if they don't find a job." $50,000 in taxes? It seems to me this would create a precarious, disenfranchised class of people within the borders of wealthy countries - much like the predicament undocumented immigrants face now. Hardly a utopia. Bregman also devotes a section to Esther Duflo's work on poverty. Duflo advocates using randomized controlled trials to find out "what works" in developmental aid. I am not particularly drawn to this approach. My own bias is towards simply asking local leadership and the people you would like to help what they want and what they would find helpful, rather than conducting what I imagine are rather expensive studies. I'm not deluded into thinking that people will always ask for what's best for them (I have my own regular forays to the convenience store for Cheetos and ice cream to prove otherwise). It just seems rather disturbingly imperialist to go trotting around the world telling people that you've empirically proven what's best for them.

When bankers go on strike, nothing major happens; when municipal workers strike, all hell breaks lose (atleast in the US, in India we have a much higher tolerance to seeing garbage on our streets; case in point the repeated strike in Delhi which seem to yield minimal results because, well we've got other problems of municipal budgetary mismanagement here so let me just stop). Utopia For Realists – And How We Can Get ThereBy Rutger BregmanA collection of ideas for social and taxation policy reform intermixed with interesting drawbacks to history. The author lays out a number of the main ideas you may have already heard being discussed in policy circles around universal basic income, ‘housing first’, shorter working weeks, measures beyond GDP of a country’s progress etc.From recommendations from friends, I’d expected the book to be fervently anti-capitalist. It isn’t. Instead the author argues that at a certain point capitalism needs to be reframed for the problems outlined in the book and puts forward a reasonable case (e.g. a basic income is highly efficient, jobs in healthcare have positive externalities that need to be recognised through payments). An interesting take, to be sure.The part that separated this book into being more enjoyable for me, was the comparison and references to history. How attitudes have changed (or in some cases haven’t) and why they do (or don’t). There is a chapter on how ideas change perceptions and can become the accepted norm in a society. Unfortunately, it is the shortest chapter in the book and I feel it is poorer for it –it would have been better to have a larger focus on this. However, the author does get some kudos for recognising their own potential cognitive biases in putting their case forward.A note on translation. The book was originally written in Dutch and translated by Elizabeth Manton. They have done a good job and I didn’t run into any issues in reading.If these areas of reform are new/unknown to you, I think you’ll enjoy the book a lot more. If you are already acquainted with them, then it’s fairly average.3.5 stars.

Fascinating statistics on efficient strategies to correct the enormous evils of poverty and inequality. I’m convinced that the proposed solutions have merit but I’m not convinced the necessary cultural change is remotely possible. I completely agree that most people in highest paying jobs work very little and wouldn’t be missed if they quit showing up. I’ve seen the truth of fundamental inequality. The work we claim to value most isn’t the work that’s paid the most. How many times have we heard that “children are our future” and no job is more important than caring for our children. Yet look at how little we pay for daycare, how little we pay teachers. Pediatricians aren’t the highest paid medical professionals. Are the top 1% actually smarter, harder working, and more innovative than 3,500,000,000 other people put together?If any of the 36 richest people in the world never came in to work again, would anything be different for the billions struggling to survive?The one thing the rich and powerful people do better than the poor and powerless is skillfully rigging the system to strengthen their grip on wealth and power.

There are a no. of bleak books about the future. To counter them, there are books like Enlightenment Now: The Case for Reason, Science, Humanism, and Progress and The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Evolves which tell you how much we have progressed historically. But this one comes up with bold, fresh ideas on how we can build a better future.The book deals with a no. of issues like universal basic income, inequality, automation/artificial intelligence, "bullshit jobs" (eg. banking/financial industry/advertising etc), a (possible) 15-hour work week , open borders, foreign aid and GDP to name a few !Each chapter with an issue and presents food-for-thought. Are open borders really possible ? What impact will universal basic income have ? How should we measure GDP ? Do highly-paid "knowledge economy" jobs create wealth or shift wealth ? Should we shift to a 15-hour work week. Even if the ideas seemed far-fetched, they got me thinking. And they were not hammered as in a political polemic. However, please note that he was writing keeping "The Land of Plenty" - the developed world in mind.

This book is primarily dedicated to advocating for three good ideas: universal basic income, the 15-hour work week, and open borders. It marshals plenty of historical evidence and contemporary statistics in support of its arguments, and what's more, it is a breezy, light-hearted, good-natured read. It's a great book to get you thinking about these topics, and why so many us have knee-jerk reactions that say these things could never happen.Bregman encourages us to understand that we have to develop an idea of a better world to work towards; that we are not stuck in a perpetual, unchanging present. If the Utopias of the past no are no longer useful, we must develop new ones. If we have no idea what a better society might look like, we sure as hell aren't likely to get there. Though the book makes use of many real-life examples, the approach to discussing these topics is somewhat abstract in the sense that there isn't much if any serious discussion of the main obstacles to implementing any progress toward Utopian goals that he describes. That's the book's main shortcoming and why I dock it a star. There are, of course, real material interests that benefit from the status quo, and they fight tenaciously to protect their privilege and wealth. Good luck making much progress toward a more equitable society without dismantling the institutions that support our current inequitable arrangements. But maybe that's a longer book and not that one that Bregman was setting out to write, which fair enough I guess. As it stands, this is still a fun, enjoyable read that engages with radical ideas in an accessible way. It would make a good gift for the budding lefty in your life who is still finding his or her footing.

This is a highly informative book about what we can do to fix all the economic problems we're having in the world, and no one will read it and no politicians will pay attention to it."In fact, it has been highly profitable NOT to innovate.Imagine how much progress we've missed out on because thousands of bright minds have frittered away dreaming up hypercomplex financial products that are ultimately only destructive. Or spent the best years of their life duplicating existing pharmaceuticals in a way that's infinitesimally different enough to warrant a new patent application by a brainy lawyer so a brilliant PR department can launch a brand-new marketing campaign for the not-so-brand-new drug.A long time ago Friedrich Engels described the "false consciousness" to which the working class of his day - the "proletariat" - had fallen victim. According Engels, the nineteenth-century factory worker didn't rise up against the landed elite because his world view was clouded by religion and nationalism. Maybe society is stuck in a comparable rut today, except at the very top of the pyramid. Maybe some of those people at the top have their vision clouded by all the zeros on their paychecks, the hefty bonuses, and the cushy retirement plans. Maybe a fat billfold triggers a similar false consciousness: the conviction that you're producing something of value BECAUSE you earn so much."

As for the practical ideas in the book, none of them seemed particularly revolutionary or radical to me- in fact, I’d say he doesn’t go far enough sometimes, but I am heavily left-leaning, so I imagine some of it might be quite shocking to people who are less politically involved or more centrist/right wing. However, I did enjoy the book for its true purpose: a plea for the necessity of Utopian ideas. The author is well-aware that his proposed plans seem unrealistic to most people (although, mind you, they are really not). Even so, he manages to make you aware of the importance of wanting the world to be better than it is. His lust for new ideas, especially ‘unrealistic’ ones, is very infectious. I dare say, modern leftists could learn a thing or two from that. I intend on re-reading this book, to filter out the really good bits that have to to with that Dare-To-DDream type stuff. I recommend this book, but don’t go into this book expecting hardcore leftism. The fact that sometimes it misses the mark slightly does make it more enjoyable to read though, in my personal opinion at least, because it gives you something to engage with, rather than just saying “yes, exactly” to yourself for a couple hundred pages.

This book has an excellent translator, who managed to take the Dutch and turn it into English that's colloquial and uses references understood in any English-language country. Bravo on the translation! The topic itself is timely and necessary. If we want to actually move into a more equitable world not driven by greed, unrelenting work, and downward-spiraling wages as we wait for machines (physical robots or computers) to take our jobs, then this is a good read. As always, utopias are difficult to imagine unless we start working towards them, and the author does make that point to try to get the reader over the hump of thinking his ideas are impossible. As he suggests, I would think we should try as a society some of these ideas in a modern context (like universal income trials like Ontario tried only to be axed by Doug Ford's government) to see if they work. One thing I really appreciated is the mythbusting the author undertakes to show that people (especially poor people) are not inherently lazy or undeserving of a living wage, even a guaranteed one for all, where we get to lift everyone out of poverty and help unbalance the inequities in a neo-liberal world.

I loved this comforting book that says a lot of things I'd already encountered from other books about Universal Basic Income, poverty, debt, and bullshit jobs for instance. In a different book about the dystopia we're currently living in and where it's headed, QualityLand, the AI running for president asks the question, "For generations you have been told that you would only have to shovel coal for a while longer, then the train would take you to paradise. Have you ever considered that you have long since arrived in paradise but forgotten to get off?" And this book asks this question a lot, too. Our productivity is so high that we could afford to be less productive in other areas, areas that matter. But we don't. Instead, we try to make healthcare and education "more productive", too. We could work fewer hours. But we don't. Instead, a lot of us work overtime in jobs that do not add anything at all to the good of society. We could devote ourselves to bettering our condition. But we don't. Instead, we have become "caretakers of the museum of history" and believe that bettering our condition is no longer possible. The author laments that our world has developed in such a way that broad societal improvement has become unthinkable. We have no utopias any more because we've shaped ourselves in such a way that we deny ourselves to think about them. He shows what is possible, what has been proven possible, and tries to embolden the reader to embrace the ability to have utopian notions and actively try and better the world.

I forgot to review this a month or so ago when I read it, but it has stayed on my mind since! Bregman is arguing for three major changes in humanity: 1) Universal basic income, 2) The 15-hour work week, and 3) Open borders internationally. His arguments for basic income are the strongest. He cites many, many places where this has been tried and has proven successful. This section alone makes the book a nourishing meal for thought. Again, his thought experiments are very persuasive. I wish every adult would read this and we could have a giant national and international conversation about how to implement Bregman's ideas!

Some of the topics include universal basic income, open borders, and cash substitutes.The topics and probable outcomes have been very well researched and presented in a believable way.Not that this has anything directly to do with the book. But just thinking that some of the governments in charge currently in South Africa, Russia, USA, Zimbabwe etc. Doesn't really seem like Utopia is attainable.Regardless, this is an easy recommendable book if you are interested in the topic.

4.5*A seminal piece of work to build foundational ideas around what a utopian welfare state might look like (basic income, less work week hours, open borders). The book is a more 'popular-science' take on understanding the socio-political issues of the current world - has bits of details from works across history, economics, political science, psychology. Kept thinking of this as a wonderful complimentary read to 'Winners Take All'.Rutger Bregman understands he's describing extremely radical ideas, but encourages readers to build the skill to embrace it. To have a vivid view of a glorious future, and not just be running away from a bad present. For some parts, he's almost a motivational speaker. As evident from his talks, he is strongly opinionated (which he admits in between) which can be an issue as he's quoted tons of experiments and stats, most of which can have heavy selection bias. It also goes to show how little solid scientific work is done in these fields. The book is definitely a strong thought-starter - hopeful of a future built with big, radical ideas.

Well, the cover of the book tells you the key things the author has in mind for a Utopia. Universal Basic Income, open borders and 15 hour work week.The realist in me disagrees vehemently that that utopia is achievable universally. It honestly does feel that Bregman is viewing at the whole thing from the perspective of a citizen of a developed nation. I can't fathom how any of those ideas can possibly be implemented in a country like India.Still, there are plenty of very fascinating ideas in the book. I think it will merit a second reading and a good deal of thought to understand applicability in different kinds of societies. The book also probes a fair amount of introspection of the cause of all the stress, and the inherent value of the "work" most of us do. That itself is a great achievement - regardless of your views on whether the ideas presented here are socialistic, against free market, populist, etc.

I decided to read this book when I saw him in a clip from a Tucker Carlson show (trust me, I don't watch that show). I was impressed that Bregman very calmly suggested that wealth inequality was at the heart of social problems (which set Carlson into a mindless rant). The book has the same quality of simplicity and common sense, backed by reference to multiple studies to prove his points. He points out that many of the solutions we think we've developed to social issues, like poverty, illiteracy, homelessness, etc, aren't working and we don't even realize it because we don't test our theories with data. We keep doing the same things that haven't worked the first, second or multiple times. He then suggests some innovative and, in some cases shocking to many, solutions based on research that has been done and ignored.

Books like this -- factual, non-fiction -- are usually tough sledding for me, but this one was a downhill race! I found this book compulsively readable, even though I think I figured most of this stuff out a long time ago. It's satisfying to have a better researcher provide foundations for ideas that I can hardly justify by myself! Bregman writes, "...Whereas in 1970 twice as many male Harvard grads were still opting for a life devoted to research over banking, twenty years later, the balance had flipped, with one and a half times as many alumni employed in finance." I was one of those Harvard grads that went into research: what does a good life look like? The book's conversational, accessible style, due I’m sure in part to a graceful translation from the original Dutch by Elizabeth Manton, is conversational and easy, despite the fact that it is highly seasoned with interesting but hard to swallow facts. I agree with many of the blurb writers: reading this book should be compulsory.

I've been wanting to read this book for a while now, having seen it on bookshelves everywhere, from Beirut to Berlin. Due to a power outage that took away the distraction of my laptop, I finished this in two days. It was really a breeze to read through (compared to A theory of moral sentiments) I think every one should read this book, because at the very least, it will give our generation of depressed people something hopeful to look forward to. The book opens with. "...the real crisis of our times, of my generation, is not that we don't have it good, or even that we might be worse off later on. No, the real crisis is that we can't come up with anything better."Then we arrive at the main discussion of the three bold ideas: the establishment of a Universal basic income, a 15-hour workweek, and open borders. The author backs up each of these with hard evidence: research proves that, contrary to our perception or stigmas, they work.But certainly, is this book too naive? "Remember: those who called for the abolition of slavery, for suffrage of women, and for same-sex marriage were also once branded lunatics. Until history proved them right." "The difficulty lies, not in the new ideas, but in escaping from the old ones. - John Maynard Keynes"

4.5 - «Utopias do not offer answers - they ask the right questions» In short, I think it is worth reading. The theme is undeniably relevant, the author prepared, and the writing fluid, pleasant and non-technical without falling into simplisms - and this is important.It goes through a necessary recompilation of important concepts, stats, experiments and experiences that help to escape from what now seem to be truisms but which probably would not really resist after being properly questioned. The choice of the title of the book is certainly exaggerated and bombastic, as (necessarily) it does not offer an overall and complete recipe for solving among the biggest problems facing humanity, but rather reiterates the importance of taking (again) in consideration a series of solutions that today may seem radical but which, in the end, are nothing more than reasonable.

Bregman takes care in making ideas such as Universal Basic Income and the 15 hour work week seem plausible. The book is concise and an enjoyable read with plenty of anecdotes to support his theories including cases in which UBI has worked in the past. He also disproves some of the time old arguments against changing the status quo. Most importantly though Utiopia for Realists tackles the issue with its own ideas. Namely that politicians dismiss them out of hand as being radical despite themselves enacting radical theories on the other end of the spectrum. Also that the very people who we need to be enacting these ideas or at least arguing for their efficacy aren't doing so in a verbose or meaningful way. The onus is in the reader who is convinced that these ideas could work to spread the word and organise.

Reading this book is timely in light of coverage of the recent federal election in Australia (where I live), and the shitshow that is American politics and Brexit. Rutger is exploring the argument for a universal basic income, a restructuring of the way we think about, classify and do work, and a range of other "radical" (or not so radical, depending on your political spectrum) policy proposals.But the most important messages of this book are not specific to a particular policy, but rather are a call to arms for a reinjection of idealism in politics. For a set of policies that are not reactionary, or backward looking, but forward looking, hopeful and question who we all are and where we want to go together. It is a reminder that we are not buffeted on the winds of change, but rather the society we have is the result of our own actions; at any point in time we can choose something different. It is also a reminder that progressive agendas during historical periods of industrial, social and technological revolution are often seen as radical until they become so normal that they are taken for granted.

Wow, I love this book! I listened to an audio version, but after finishing, I bought a hard copy!He makes clear, simple, and compelling arguments that recognize how good we have it, insist on our need to have a utopian ideal to strive for, lays out how imminent some very utopian ideas (have been and) are, and gives hopeful directions to move in.He touches on such a broad collection of thoughts, ideas, histories, studies, projects, plans, and politics with such ease and fluidity that it left me astounded at how he managed to squeeze them into such a small book. I look forward to reading more of Bregman's works and hope that he continues to gain traction.If you have any interest in making the world a better place, I can't recommend this book enough!

This book raises a number of interesting ideas, from outdated predictions of the future to a solid argument for universal basic income. (For which I am now a proponent, given how redundant it makes many US government programs look.) On the whole I think it's great discussion fodder and centered around fascinating concepts. That said, Bregman's writing is... well... dry. And I don't think his narration of the audiobook helps. Unlike sociological writers who adopt a narrative tone (I'm thinking Barbara Ehrenreich here), I think Bregman's approach is academic and thus dry. That said, I'd love to see this book assigned for high school or college courses to spur discussion. I also look forward to talking about it over dinner with friends.

Energetic but anecdotal and fragmented. While humane and engaged in re-staking a leftist claim on proposing a persuasive utopian vision after ' neo-liberalism conquered the economic agenda, and rightist populism secured a monopoly on religion and immigration, the reader is not left with a coherent/comprehensive proposal for a future societal order, but a set of rather random pitches for topics like basic citizen pay, cash donations instead of social and foreign aid plus open borders.Still many sharp and acute angels on current topics provide a good destination for the casual opinion shopper

Good statement of facts, examination on current level of inequality in the world and many thought-provoking ideas on how to move forward on the issue. On the other hand lacks more detailed solutions, however, turns out this is not the attempt of the book - one who expects airtight calculations on how to introduce e.g. unconditional basic income will be disappointed. Rather a book for the masses which is doing a good job in educating about the current discussion. It tries to put some seemingly radical measures within a closer reach of what society today thinks is possible, inviting to further debate about the topic.

An eye-opening and entertaining read. Bregman's central argument is that we shouldn't assume that the current state of the world is entirely natural and immutable. Rampant inequality and global poverty should not be things that we readily accept. Bregman has a few ideas on how we can change this, and in this book, he shares how he believes universal basic income, open borders, and a shorter workweek could help bring us closer to a more utopian world.Near the end of the book, Bregman talks about how great change usually comes in times of crisis. Amid the Coronavirus pandemic, ideas like universal basic income, student debt forgiveness, rent control are now finding new and unexpected support.Time will tell if Bregman's utopia will come to pass, but I can only hope that the tide will start to shift as more of us become increasingly dissatisfied with the lackluster promises of our politicians.

I very rarely give 5 star reviews, but this book hit the right spot for me in the current phase of my life. For a couple of years I've been dreaming about not having to worry about the basics so that I could devote my time to what I really care most about. And that wouldn't be a "bullshit job" as the author defines it, but something with more depth, more meaning and more potential for self fulfilment. And I like my job, I can't even imagine how I'd feel if I didn't... but still, If I could, I would use my time to do different things. Easy read, highly recommended!

The author has many ideas that at first seem totally unrealistic (open borders, a basic income). But he makes a strong case for why these concepts are possible. I had no idea, for example, that we almost got basic income under President Nixon (for real). I particularly enjoyed the chapters about GDP and open borders. The author has such an engaging voice. Reading this felt like an enjoyable conversation. Overall, it gave me hope! Oh, and I learned that The Netherlands has the shortest work week--another reason to move there!

By far the best manifesto for a better future that I have read to date. Includes universal basic income, shorter work weeks, open borders, the nonsense of the GDP, bullshit jobs, and many more aspects. Very well written, the book goes far beyond the superficial musings of a Yuval Noah Harari and is instead well-founded in research. What is missing is the concrete implementation of these ideas, apart from the many experiments that have been run. Nevertheless, this book should be required reading for many, especially the Millenials who are about to take over society.

A thought provoking read.Bregman puts forward a suite of reforms that we - the rich, Western world - can use to eradicate poverty abroad and at home, or at least tackle it. He advocates a radical vision of open borders, among other things. Like any 'popular' book, in the process of dumbing down complex ideas one can often lose meaning, context, or fall victim of reductionism. For example, a cause of concern is the number of 'myths' Bregman 'debunks' with a short stroke of the pen. Immigrants don't force down wages, Bregman argues, citing one report to the effect. What does this mean, and how can we take this as truth: seperated research has said the opposite. Bregman also notes (p2) that in present day Netherlands a homeless person receiving public assistance has more to spend than the average Dutchman. True, no doubt, but meaningless if not contextualised and relativised against, say, the purchasing power of those two protagonists in their respective periods. These are just a few examples of a thread of ahistorical examples in Bregmans book.In fact, rather belatedly (p237) Bregman concedes that when reality clashes with our deepest convictions, rather than change them we recalibrate our worldview. Known as cognitive dissonance, on the same page Bregman admits that he too has discarded empirical evidence to suit his narrative. The cognitive dissonance accusation can be levelled at Bregman. A thought-provoking read, and definitely worth it, but take it with a pinch of salt. Despite this, Bregman does well to tackle a series of complex issues and his book serves as a primer to more academic text.

Well reasoned arguements for Bregman's three points (15 hour workweek, open borders, and universal basic income). Makes it seem inevitable that we move that direction, but as always I'm left with the greater question of how. How, if we like a certain policy can we make it happen? Especially from ourside the system. I ran for office in part to try and solve that, but for these issues the activation energy is so much higher. To his credit, Bregman addresses that briefly in the epilogue, though without providing a pathway. Thanks to Lada for the recommendation!

It's been a long time that a book challenged my core ideals. That forced me to think about them.Do I agree with everything Rutger proposed? No but he did made me think about the why. Also I had so many conversations with my partner about this. I discovered he's more of socialist then I am. He's also weirdly optimistic about the idea of an Utopia. Which is weird because of the two of us I get called the positive one. We do have very different backgrounds so maybe that's why... But I'm more nature oriented and he is more people oriented.It was a fascinating read. And I'm really glad I gifted this to my partner and then read it first.

I was expecting more utopia and science fiction out of this book but it's actually a book about economy, a case for universal basic income, rise of bullshit jobs and open borders (mainly about freedom of workforce movement). Such book of course cannot get without describing various cognitive fallacies (+1 for Kahneman). According to economic calculations it would be cheaper to give homeless people a home for free than deal with the negative consequences and spillover effects, similarly just giving poor people money yields better results and brings less than anticipated negative effects than highly organized external foreign aid campaigns. I did not find the case for UBG that convincing, author keeps referring to the "high-grade" experiments in Finland but according to my latest knowledge the findings form there were not that convincing. I'm definitely a big supporter of free labor movement but this has to be thought through in a better way to avoid major backlashes.

The underdog socialists' biggest problem isn't that they're wrong. Their biggest problem is that they are dull. Dull as a doorknob. They've got no story to tell, nor even any language to convey it in. Fantastic book and an eye-opener for myself, one of many people disappointed with the state of social democracy and politics today. Clear, driven manifesto for basic income, a 15-hour work week and a revision of the relationship between labour, capital and people.

Don't have any strong feelings about this book to be honest. Introduced a lot of interesting ideas but remained fairly surfacial about them without ever fully engaging with counter arguments or diving deep into data. While some topics were thought provoking - namely, the idea of a utopia (or it's very existence as a thought) as a sign of the future and as an indicator of cultural relevance, others were just damn right arrogant for how casually they were spoken about without fully augmenting the counter narratives in the argument.

Really interesting book on some concepts like universal basic income, direct cash grants to the poor, and the 15 hour work week. These ideas aren’t new per se,but much of the data that he uses is new to me and changed some of my perspectives. The only reason that I dock it a star is I actually doubt some of his conclusions based on the data. To his credit, he talks about confirmation bias but then never really lets it affect the rest of the book. Interesting read.

Let's call people who prefer the status quo and act to uphold it 'agents of the establishment'. One of the ways agents of the establishment preserve the status quo is by making you feel ridiculous, wild, and stupid for thinking things could be different. They shame you into silence and acceptance. For most of us, it's really hard to mount a counter-offensive and show just how sensible an alternative could be. So we don't, and we sit there discontent, powerless, and embarrassed.Fortunately, Rutger Bregman actually studies these things and has the time to mount that counter-offensive. Utopia for Realists is just that: a counter-offensive against the proposition that the way things are is the only realistic way they could be.If you want to learn how to talk about building a world of less work (most of us aren't so fortunate as to work our dream jobs, so less work effectively means more time to do what we love), less poverty, and more migratory freedom, then this book is for you. And we all should learn how to talk about these things, because it sucks that the establishment has the upper hand just because it is incumbent, when there are better, saner, fairer ideas out there.

This book is the antidote to “Enlightenment Now” – who’s entirety can be summed up by Utopia for Realist’s first sentence “In the past, everything was worse”. There are real bold social proposals in here backed up by persuasive arguments. I greatly appreciate Bergman’s relationship to data and research studies, owning up to the errors/biases that have occurred but that we take as fact and highlighting the immeasurable. Worthy read!

I think this book is less radical than it was when first published in 2014, because the ideas have largely gone around. The main thing I disliked was the heavy focus on USA. The author isn't even American! He did keep it a bit more global, but even still it's so bloody American focused. Maybe I agreed with the ideas so much because he was also critical of USA. Perfect country to show flaws of lol Reading time: 4.2 hours

Started off with a basic overview of the arguments and stats around universal income, which was a bit dry and retrod old ground for anyone who has followed the debate. However the book really got going about halfway through with interesting stories and even managed to retell some classics with new insight (eg the story of the Luddites‘s failed battle again the weaving loom). Nicely summarised a number of leading progressive thinkers and heterodox economists. Highly recommended.

In this, the age of the "Thought Leader" ("you know I'm a thought leader because I've just done this with my hands"), this is the kind of book we get.I object to the title. It should be "An Argument for Universal Basic Income for Technocrats". You know, those people who believe "Enlightenment Now" and don't see color. This book ignores so much that really needs to be talked about if we're talking about income inequality and the future of work and wealth.

Read for bookclub, nothing I'd pick up myself, but in the end, found it quite interesting. As someone who find philosophy much more intriguing, I was sad to find that much of the book deals with economics, which is obvious when dealing with the idea of a Utopia. All in all, the author did a great job introducing complex ideas for the layperson.

I mean, of course I liked it, because it was a book basically telling me why the opinions I already hold are right. But it was nice to hear practical, meaningful ideas for progress at a time when the left seems to be split between "the same shit as the right but with a blm sticker on it" and "academic theories that they have no intention of trying to actually apply". It was also interesting, accessible, and well written.

I found this book to be very one-sided and hence only vaguely relevant. I might not give it its credit but the thing is that because it is my first book on the topic, does not offer a general overview and appears very biased and slightly naive, I cannot really assess it or take much from it. But I definitely did like it more toward the end.

Incredibly well researched and structured argument for progress. The problem identified in the book, that statistics can be massaged or presented in certain ways to support a particular argument, may apply. An Orwell quote used multiple times was presented as if supporting the book's argument but in context was entirely the opposite.

3.5 stars. Very easy to read and lots of thought provoking new ideas to mull over. However, the structure of the book is a bit unclear - he has three key ideas overall which are unequally attended to and it is unclear when he transitions from one idea to the next. Specifically, he doesn’t spend much time on the idea of open borders. However, a fascinating and important read nonetheless

While studying economics in Canada these were all the issues I was looking for answers to. Never thought there was still hope in solving these and all within one book. Now as a budding activist (in my free time) I would love to involved in realizing even one of these ideas. A start is definitively reading this book so we can at least start considering the lot. Enjoy!

Having read quite a few anti-capitalist books in recent years (many that Bregman's cites too), there was little new here. But the author tells a good story and his focus on universal basic income is important. Four stars because of the knee-jerk rhetoric familiar in this genre, where the author just has to bash the left in order to sound more legitimate in the ears of the right--who won't be listening anyway. A bit sad, but says a lot about our times. Recommended.

3.5This is an aspirational rather than practical book, despite the title. Bregman thoroughly covers history and research to challenge the modern acceptance of work-focused, late-stage capitalism. And he relates it all in a punchy, quip-laden style that I found engaging. However, after diagnosing the problems that many recognize (we work too much, we spend money on the wrong things, and we don't treat people the way we say we should), he stops short of providing truly realistic cures for the disease. Still, this book has forced me to think about how to do better; so in that regard, it absolutely succeeded.

A great journey, outlining the pathway to meaningful reduction in poverty worldwide as well as a more satisfying life in the developed work. It ends with a rallying cry for "the underdog socialists" to buck up and drive forward real social change. Would recommend for the converted and sceptics alike!

The 'how we can get there' part promised in the title seems almost entirely lacking, boiling down essentially to 'don't give up'. Apart from that this is a mostly interesting summary of historical experiments with radical progressive policies and bemoaning their abandonment. The title is far more exciting than the content.

While I agree with many of the ideas and the sentiments behind them, I just wish the book was more rigorous in its arguments. Like most popular political economy books it was a good skim of the surface, but, in my case, the end felt lacking. Likely a good book for someone who has no background on the topic.

Very good introduction to some of the new, groundbreaking ideas that will probably dominate the discussions of the next decades.Sadly, from the perspective of someone who already has some knowledge about economic ideas like an unconditional basic income the book did not offer much new. Better for people who are not familiar with these topics.
Everyone should read this book. It is so thought provoking and points out that things don't have to be the way they are now. It's not a blueprint for change, though -- just a springboard for thought.

I thought this was really great. The ideas presented in this book are so important and relevant and their time has come. I think this book is extremely timely and that more people need to read it and spread the ideas held within.

"Be unrealistic, unreasonable and impossible." You've heard me rant about Olivia Laing's The Lonely City. You've audibly sighed as I bring up Briohny Doyle's Adult Fantasy one more time. Now get ready for the next book I want to force you all to read: Rutger Bregman's Utopia for Realists. It's optimistic – or perhaps just realistic. It reads like a dream – but a dream that you should take seriously, remembering that giving women the vote was once a preposterous idea. His vision of Utopia is based around a universal basic income, a 15 hour work week, and a world without borders – all big ideas to tackle in 264 pages. But they are passionately and persuasively argued for, as are his side campaigns to prove why the GDP is not an appropriate measurement of success in the modern day, and to highlight the "bullshit" of capitalism. That's the bullshit of many jobs, and the bullshit of a society that consistently picks consumerism over leisure.

The book offered everything I search for in reading non-fiction and what makes it so enjoyable for me: it widend my view, made me think and question given ideas or opinions and above all encouraged me to learn more about a field, like economics in that case, I use to shy away from.

Fantastic book. Read this just after I've read Sapiens.This is a great addition/ follow up ons the most important themes of our current society.What is work? What is well-being? And how are we stuck in a system we've created our self and are sometime too blind to look through.Must read!

Brilliant, forward-thinking ideas that could change the world for the better, presented in simple language for all to understand and connect with.People who want to believe in creating a better life for more of human kind will feel more hopeful after this read. Here's the vision, let's spread the message and work on the execution.

I really liked the ideas this book brings up.Yes, some of them sound pretty crazy, but it's a good argument that many things socially and technologically sound crazy before their time. When might be the time for open borders, universal basic income, 15 hour work week? Soonish?

A must-read! Recommended to all interested in the "utopias" of UBIs, a world without workaholism, and inequality. Its a shame when you realize the world is full of smart persons working on ways to sell people more stuff they dont need for money they dont have.

A quick read with not that much data and few stories because basic income has few actual studies. This book could have been shorter with more comparisons of tax rates to propsperity. Largely, I enjoyed the diferrent take on GDP being arbitrary, basic income being largely established through the Canadian, UK, and European trials. The book is worth the read, yet you are left without much of a join the movement and more self organize after reading this book... Andrew Yang may change this...

Wonderful book. Read it in 2 go. Covers several interesting arguments for Universal Basic Income, flawed system of GDP, poverty and remedial measures , job market, importance of leisure. And supported by research and tests conducted by randomistas. Interesting quotes. It was full worth it read.

The author presents some interesting ideas about improving particular aspects of society, especially related to poverty, how we measure economic growth, the amount of time we spent at work, and the efficiency of border policy. Highly recommended for those looking for fresh perspectives.

~3.5Very interesting and informative. It's a pretty easy read but there was one or two chapters that had me confused only because I couldn't grasp the concepts behind them (mainly GDP, that no matter how many times I read it, I was still confused by it as a concept).

Promissed answers on the cover, sadly only described ideas and why they might be worth doing. I would have loved more thoughts about how to get everyone moving towards that utopia. We for sure need to start working on that.

Bregman shifts the utility of "utopia" from that of an outcome-based blueprint to a questions-based process, so you don't have to agree with all of his solutions in order to appreciate the visionary way he in which he frames the problems of automation, inequality, globalization, and more. While I am not convinced that his three flagship ideas logically mesh with each other, the focus on the process of coming up with ideas is a really helpful way to think about how to achieve idealistic yet realistic progress. It's also a quick and easy book to read.
"Utopia for Realists" is a refreshing and very enlightening read with plenty to think about in the way we deal with poverty, work, banking and much more.
Super motivating as it points a Possible Positive Future where Basic Income and Working Time reductions are the new components of the Digital Age Societies. #mustread
Simply put, an urgent and necessary book. Thank you Rutger Bregman.
A book which proves to be a roadmap for future and in no ways it's unrealistic. It shows you how certain things which are unimaginable can actually benefit the society as a whole.
The epilogue is the best part. I think most of my friends would like this book.

Opens to eye to a few ideas like basic universal income, the 15 hour work week and the opening of national borders for labour, all the while referencing several experiments and statistics that disproved many of the fears and dogmas around these ideas. A compilation of anecdotes and studies encourages the reader to rethink about problems such as unemployment and inequality between classes and nations. Did not completely reassure me that these ideas would actually work as the experiments and statistics make believe, but it is a good start. Lacks a bit more depth on how these ideas would be implemented or funded.
Not just hope, but a vision for a progressive future. So much better than just the "oh no please don't hurt us" rhetoric that has characterized so much of the Trumpian era progressive response.
Eye opening. And (hopefully) world changing.
Time to join the revolution? Certainly will get you thinking.
Read this! This is a really accessible look at universal income and other related subjects using some interesting data and case studies.
Great ideas and very inspiring about the possible future of humanity. If, that is, we survive our current climate crisis.
Wow, it's hilarious to read this in Egypt!

Mixed bag.I heard about Bregman after he totally triggered Tucker Carlson on air, and was curious to see what else he had to say. This book is a collection of some of the economist's insights into how to make sweeping societal progressions and thinking big. And I'll admit, some of it was amazing! He leads with his strongest argument for a Universal Basic Income, which is brilliant and should absolutely be done tomorrow. Sign me up. But then he loses me with some of his less convincing arguments, like for a shorter work week. When he argues for Open Borders, I was almost ready to write him off; but I think that might be a translating error, as he seems to be making the case for drastically increased migration rates. I'm 100% on board with that, but not "Open Borders"; but the text was not originally written in English, so it's possible that the terms got mixed up somewhere.
Worth reading whether you're liberal or conservative. Some great things to ponder with lots of research and studies to back it up. Great discussion points to bring up at dinner with relatives. *wink*
This book changed my thought process on so many things I thought I already new about.
Well-written (in a way that made it a very accessible read, unlike much nonfiction about economics or politics), insightful, hopeful.
Really interesting book with some great ideas. Arguments are well laid out and considered from both sides. I only hope some of the ideas can be implemented in my lifetime.
Basically a good overview of why Basic Income is a good idea. With data and stuff. Like, it would actually help its no joke.Give it a read
One of the easiest yet stimulating book to read. Great read to make for an exciting weekend.
Very practical. If everyone took off the blinkers and listened to this we would sort the world out in short order.

I enjoyed how such radical ideas are introduced along with sociological experiments that make the ideas seem maybe not so radical after all. This was quite mind opening. The book had me thinking of many what-ifs.

I knew this guy had to be good when I saw him make Tucker Carlson look like an idiot on his own show. We'll I'm sure that's not too hard to do, but the way he did it made me want to know more. Then I saw Rutger Bregman on the Daily Show giving an interview and found out he had a book and here I am. The three big things he touches on are what's on the cover: Universal Basic Income, 15 hour work week, and open borders. Before reading this book I felt these things might be good, but are politically possible. BRILLIANT IDEAS MARRED BY POOR EVIDENCE AND CHEAP POLITICISINGIt’s difficult to give this book 2 stars, especially when the premises are something I really do agree with but there were far too many noticeable issues both with the writing and it’s content. Where to start...?Bregman presents three ideas - a shorter working week, a universal basic income and open borders. I understand the book is intend to be ‘popular’ and Bregman himself states “If you can’t explain your ideal to a fairly intelligent twelve-year old [...] it’s probably your own fault”. Sadly, Bregman stops at the level of a twelve-year-old and ultimately this book resembles a GCSE or A-Level style essay. THE EVIDENCE I found many assertions by the author where I’d look for a source to back it up to find Bregman had not bothered to give one, and of the sources in the Notes section at least half are quotations from novelists or opinion pieces in newspapers. He spends a lot of time talking about mechanisation and horses that sounds strikingly similar to a video on YouTube from a couple of years ago (Humans Need Not Apply) that explains the same stuff in two minutes and is common knowledge to most high school students. There’s some embarrassing lack of historical knowledge for a Historian as he implies that Luddism started in W Yorks rather than Nottinghamshire and his cobbled-together narrative of the Rawfolds Mill incident suggests he’d just looked it up in the book he sources moments before and assumes nobody will question it (I live and work about 5 minutes away from it). He crowbars in graph showing GDP from Worldmapper by Prof. Danny Dorling and co. and just leaves it there, not bothering to link this to his point within the chapter when it would have added depth and more importantly empirical evidence to what he was stating. He throws out statistics such as 47% of jobs likely to be lost to automation, not bothering to deconstruct what sectors of the economy these are in, for example, and the implications this has on his hypothesis. I understand that this book is meant to be a brief introduction and he’s a Historian not a Geographer or Economist but for someone espousing Enlightenment ideals the empirical evidence he really extrapolates from is scant in large parts (especially when you actually look at the sources and see sample sizes, method of measurement or statistical analysis).THE POLITICISATIONUnderstandable that Bregman has a political opinion and this is his book so he wants to put it across. However, others have noted that the final two chapters are less him advancing his three ideas as a cheap attack on the Left (he rightfully points out that they are often ineffective but lumps all the Left together as communistic, blue-sky thinkers) and doesn’t mention anything about the Right, even going so far as to imply that the Neoliberals are the emissaries of order, peace and all that is good - if only they listen to him! For me, presenting the powerful ideas he has requires some semblance of impartiality and would demand political concensus across the board if it is to be achieveable in the near future be he rather effectively rules this out. (I did wonder if some of his comments are meant to be the shake up the parties on the political Left need but then he descended into mud-slinging and I realised not.) I did have a good laugh a few paragraphs after Bregman decries “the underdog socialist” who only has an appeal to emotion left before he himself appeals to emotion with a weepy story of how he’s been told no by so many people but he still goes on and does what he’s doing because he believes passionately in the Utopian ideal. Do as I say and not as I do, reader.THE DELIVERYAside from the really awful adaptation of this book for the US market and the copy that I have which has a profile of the author under the banner “The Viral Sensation taking on the Billionaires”... Bregman seems to have a fixation on particular things throughout. He is fond of using idioms but not commonplace ones (he’s a non-native speaker, fair enough but the editor didn’t pick up on these?) He VERY liberally sprinkles in quotations from all and sundry (though Oscar Wilde pops up every seventh sentence seemingly) to give what I imagine he believes is a little flair to his writing. Sadly this has the opposite effect and crosses into pretention. And lastly he spends so little time examining ideas that just as you’re starting to engage with one he’s fluttering away to the next. OVERALLI went out of my way to order this book having heard of it and seen the reviews on Goodreads. It’s a shame that the potent arguments in this book were reduced to such basic points that they lost meaning and as someone who mostly agreed with the views before setting out I found myself questioning them. If I were someone who started out with opposing ideas I can certainly say that I would never have been swayed by Bregman. Perhaps this would have been much better with a different person delivering?

When trying to come up with a Dystopia, the classical recipe is simple: think of a Utopia (or several, in Rutger's case) and ask yourself how you would achieve it.The book is full of sometimes infantile, often exaggerated claims, factoids given undue weight, ideological talking points, or false statements which, at times, are also doubled by self-righteous indignation. With the exception of a few arguments, the methodology employed by the author seems simple and straightforward: - start with an idea you like, and look for "studies" or articles that contain phrases that seem to support what you already believe in (a single anecdote in an article can later be used in your favor to convince readers unfamiliar with the topic or too busy to bother checking all the references you provide anyway); - quote those paragraphs while ignoring nuance or clarifications the original authors make (in their studies, articles, etc) that might indicate a more complex picture than the one you are after;- ignore acknowledgements (from the authors of the papers your quote) about the limitations of the research you quote;- ignore acknowledgements that additional studies are required before making more definitive statements;- present your Straw-man as "what the actual Science shows" Here are a few examples:"Some scientists even contend that the first person who will live to celebrate their 1,000th birthday has already been born."Nope! No real scientist with expertise in a relevant field (e.g.: Biology) claims that. "Science"-reporting journalists are not scientists. Speculators are not scientists either."True, history is full of horrifying forms of utopianism – fascism, communism, Nazism – just as every religion has also spawned fanatical sects. But if one religious radical incites violence, should we automatically write off the whole religion? So why write off the utopianism?"The problem with this Straw-man is that, throughout history, we did not have "one religious radical" who has incited violence, but millions, at least (think of the Sunni/Shia schism; the Crusades; the expansion of Islam in Northern Africa, Iran, or Spain; the religious wars in Europe that followed the Protestant Reformation; the spread of Catholicism during the Spanish colonization of the Americas; the persecution of Hindus during Aurangzeb's rule; the Ottoman Empire; etc). Consider religious fanatics as part of the much wider pool of ideological fanaticism and the picture gets even more grim."The US border effect on the wages of equal intrinsic productivity workers is greater than any form of wage discrimination (gender, race, or ethnicity) that has ever been measured ... It's apartheid on a global scale"This is classic wordplay wrapped in a rhetorical attempt at shaming the people living in developed countries for not conforming to the ideological fantasies and the self-righteousness of Mr. Bregman. "Open borders promote immigrants’ return" Here Bregman quotes from "Understanding America’s Immigration Crisis" by Douglas S. Massey. The paper, however, is specific to US and only over a relatively short time-window. Increase that time-window from a few years to 100 years and a radically different perspective emerges. Look at immigration to other developed regions of the world and the picture will get even more complex. What's worse is that Massey's paper discusses the alleged impact of various (more strict or more relaxed) immigration policies ... not what will happen should borders be open ... this is like someone discussing the impact of more strict or more relaxed financial regulations and a Bregman -like individual cherry-picking part of the argument to pretend to make the case for no financial regulations at all."if you get people out of poverty, the average IQ goes up 3-5 points every 10 years"Most psychologists doubt such claims. Others question even the Scientific validity of IQ-tests (especially in the tails of the distributions).Immigration reform could be the key to world-wide equality.Complete nonsense. There's no evidence, no scientific study to support such a claim. What's even worse, no top-down solution to economic problems has ever worked in dynamic, large-scale, distributed and diverse environments.

Simple recipe for fixing the world: give everyone money, rather than programs and social services; slash the work week to give people time for things that matter; and open all borders. Easy right?Before you ask, "What is this guy smoking?" give hm a listen. Bregman points out that by the standards of even a century ago, we've already achieved the means of utopia: plentiful year round food supplies; temperature controlled environments, simple cures for diseases which ravaged our ancestors. Of course these benefits have not spread equally across the world, and even in wealthy countries we have plenty of stuff but are working ourselves crazy.Bregman's heavily researched yet accessible argument is that we waste enormous amounts of resources on social service programs, border security and "bullshit jobs" which merely move money around but don't create wealth or solve important problems. He further notes that most of our objections to his utopian schemes are based on prejudice and preconceptions but little actual evidence. Doesn't giving poor people money for nothing or a shorter work week mean they'll sit around drinking all day? Nope; several experiments on the Universal Basic Income (UBI) have shown just the opposite. Won't poor people make stupid purchases like drugs and unhealthy food with the money if they aren't regulated? Again no: UBI recipients in various countries and social systems tended to make strategic investments in equipment and transportation and housing. Won't open borders depress wages and lead to mass unemployment and crime? Again wrong: immigration has no net effect on wages, and can actually increase jobs since immigrants are also consumers. (Fun fact: increased policing of the U.S./Mexico border has led to MORE undocumented immigrants living permanently in the Us...because going back and forth to Mexico is so difficult.)Bregman comes down hard on the nonprofit, foreign aid and development industries, ("Why send over expensive white folks in SUVs when we can simply hand over their salaries to the poor?" p. 31) noting there is zero evidence that such aid actually accomplishes anything. He is also a harsh critic of the "underdog socialists" who react emotionally to injustice but are incapable of articulating any exciting new ideas. "And, too often, it seems as if those on the left actually like losing. As if all the failure, the doom, and the atrocities manly serve to prove they were right all along...Sadly the underdog socialist has forgotten that the story of the left ought to be a narrative of hope and progress. The greatest sin of the academic left is that it has become fundamentally aristocratic, writing in bizarre jargon that makes simple matters dazzlingly complex...What we need is a narrative that speaks to millions of ordinary people". ( p 258)There are some obvious flaws with Bregman's prescription: if everyone is getting a certain income and thus has more purchasing power it seems likely that prices would rise accordingly. And, as the proponents for Universal Basic Services point out, without a strong communal network for health care, education, sanitation etc. a private income will only go so far. There's also the simple factor of greed: the current system works pretty well for a small entrenched group of powerful people, and it won't be easy to convince them to release their grip, (Bregman recommends high taxation of financial transfers to encourage smart people to go into education, science and research rather than hedge funds).But like I said, give him a listen. There are young, progressive Congressional leaders: (Ocasio-Cortez, Tlaib, Omar, Underwood) who are speaking his language. It's time for cranky underdog socialists like myself to give them space.
