I wish I'd been able to read this in 2014 when it was first published in Dutch. It's well worth reading, but I'm reviewing Utopia for Realists in 2020, which is lightyears from 2014 ideologically. Rutger Bregman's book is a three-headed defense of "utopian" policies, covering universal basic income, a 15-hour-workweek, and open borders. In 2014 these were radical ideas. In 2020 they're on the table. Note that I already broadly agreed that these three ideas were good ones before I read Utopia for Realists, so I can't say how well Rutger's arguments hold up against a total non-believer, but I think it would be hard to mount an evidence-based opposition. Rutger employs a blend of instructional historical examples and hard economic data to back up his claims that 1) these policies are possible and 2) these policies would be good economically and socially/morally. Utopia for Realists is short, but I must admit its steady rhythm of "Here's a societal problem, here's a story about how it got fixed, here's the utopian policy, here's some data and another example to prove it's not utopian," got repetitive by the end. The writing is very accessible (which is a big positive for a popular history/economics book) but also somewhat bland. This book was originally released in Dutch, but since Bregman is fluent in English I'm not sure if he/the publisher simply translated it or rewrote it. Still, I think the accessibility is more of an asset than a detriment. The utility of this book is high, because it lays out the case for important but radical-seeming policies in terms and arguments anyone can understand and get behind. You might think the policy focus means Utopia for Realists will soon age to the point of not being worth reading, but the real takeaway (and the reason I think this book will be considered a classic of popular politics/economics) is not the specific "utopian" policies, but Rutger's way of seeing them. In the book's final chapter, Rutger spends some time discussing Milton Friedman in a positive light. I've been fascinated by Milton ever since I first read about him and Rutger finally illuminated why. At a time when social democracy was the standard economic model, Milton Friedman was able to convince an entire generation of economists that greed is actually good and that society will be better if we let the greedy be as greedy as they like. In 1960 this was a radical fringe idea, but by 1980 it had become the bedrock of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher's economic policies. Even for those of us who detest Milton's ideas, his progression from fringe thinker to foundational thinker is instructive. If the neoclassical economists could do it, so can today's social democrats, and even those further left than that. The past six years have only proven Rutger's point. (Rutger wrote a very good piece for The Correspondent about what he sees as the coming collapse of neoliberalism that illustrates this.)Since reading Utopia for Realists, I've become a fan of Rutger's writings for The Correspondent, and there he has demonstrated that he's become a more concise and effective communicator of neokeynesian economic policies. That's why I'm looking forward to his next book, Humankind. I like Utopia for Realists, but I think his new book will be an improvement in every way with an even more ambitious message.

GIST
At the end of the book, Brugman asserts that the best way to cut off the status quo is to present the most radical ideas in the most abrupt way possible. He succeeded doing that in this book, and I cannot stress how much it implored me to be more idealistic, not because for fanatical reasons, but for the sake of knowing that things can always be better. In this book, he proposes three main things: 1) basic universal income, 2) shorter workweeks, and 3) open borders for all.Key points- In Utopia for Realists, Brugman discusses some ideas that can change the way the present world operates. By reflecting on the need to have a utopia as a compass for progress, he presents radical ideas that not are backed by numbers themselves.- The first proposition of the books is the call for a universal basic income. Brugman cites numerous studies to support the benefits of providing free money to everyone. I repeat, everyone. Studies in Canada, UK, and even in developing nations have shown that the poor do not need much help, just cash.- Having money greatly reduces the mental bandwidth of the poor, allowing them to focus more on school and provide more time for their families. Brugman also debunks the common assertion that providing free money would make people lazy, however this is far from the case. With baseline money provided, it allows people to dig deeper into their own passions and to not get stuck into bullshit jobs (to be discussed later). By providing cash (no catches or requirements), poverty can be curtailed by 1) providing enough money for all basic needs and 2) allowing these individuals to reduce their mental bandwidth, preventing them from making stupid decisions that leads them deeper into the rabbit hole of poverty. In effect, providing free money levels the playing field for everyone.- Bregman argues that the figures to define the progress of an era must adopt to the needs of that era, in particular. In fact, using GDP as the yardstick for progress nowadays greatly limits the ability of policymakers to check for the progress on things that usually matter. GDP was borne of the need for a figure that represents the total production of the country in a given time span, and this was greatly beneficial during war as shipments of artilleries, ammunitions, tanks, cars, can easily account for the needs of the time—to produce more stuff to use for the war.- However, in our new age wherein world wars went into hiding, there is no incentive to detect progress purely from a production standpoint. Numerous new yardsticks were invented through the years, ranging from calculating happiness (Happiness index) to human development indices. In the end, what our generation needs is a generally agreed upon yardstick for progress that not only accounts for consumption but the overall well-being of the citizenry itself.- One of the bizarre propositions is the 15-hour workweek. In fact, Brugman argues that it inevitably leads to this. What's the point of the endless attempts for optimization in production, cutting employees and using more machines if humanity cannot have an increase in leisure. In fact, contrary to the ongoing hustle culture, typical people need good rest to become productive employees. However, since the feminist movement in the late 20th century, the average workweek of an American family skyrocketed as women entered the workforce. This is not necessarily bad per se in the context of the fight for the equality of both sexes but it also presents the backwardness of the system as supposed improvements in systems and machinery through the years have yet reduced the toil of the workforce. Having shorter workweeks should not be tied to the notions of stagnation but instead to the intrinsic needs of humans—relationships, family, and leisure.- In Chapter 7, Rutger Bregman gives a major middle finger to the finance sector as it continues to cash in on the capitalist system while actually producing nothing. In fact, if you'd compare the effects of garbage men striking to bankers striking, the effects are bewildering. When garbage men struck in New York in 1968, the city almost went into total chaos due to filth. When bankers struck in Ireland, barely nothing happened.- The truth is that humanity has been looking down on service jobs that actually provide real value while it glorifies jobs that actually just shift the location of cash in the market ladder (bankers). This is not to undermine the unarguable skill and intelligence of these bankers, yet it must also be remembered that doing something difficult and specialized does not necessarily make it useful. Furthermore, with the obvious obsession for more work, companies have created more bullshit jobs, jobs that actually create any tangible value to the world—leading to a workforce that feels hollow in its core. And this is further exacerbated by the income gap between notable service jobs—jobs whose absence can make society go berserk such as healthcare and education. Yet, the salaries of these people seem like change money to the bonuses handed out to people at Wall Street.- This new market that caters to shifters has lead to a shift in careers that focus on creating new ideas and value (scientists, innovators, and thinkers) to jobs that only shift value such as banking, corporate law, lobbying, high-frequency trading, and more. These people are getting paid just to track the market and shift preexisting wealth that is actually generated by people who focused more on creating value. How ironic. The disappointing truth is that the education system further exacerbates this by buzz words such as 21st century skills, problem-solving techniques, and more. It had become so obsessed on grooming students to fit the job market that it failed to answer if that job market provides any tangible value anyways.- Robots are here, and yes, it seems that some jobs are at their mercy. In fact, compared to previous corporations in the 60s that employed up to hundreds of thousands of people, the biggest corporations nowadays produce more but only employ half. Robots are here to stay. This automation creates the dystopian possibility that someday—humans may be demoted to creatures who just push the buttons of these robots so that they'd start doing work. As these robots eat up a huge portion of these bullshit jobs, it would be better for us to concern ourselves to not make our jobs our identity through a universal basic income and shorter workweek.- Lastly, Bregman calls for a solution to global poverty through open borders. Instead of pouring in cash through cash aids for developing nations, why not open the borders instead? We live in a society wherein your standard of living is not predetermined by talent or social class but to the country you are born in. In fact, people at the poverty line in the US enjoy far more compared to the poorest people in developing countries. The existence of borders has lead to a segregation of the standard of living of people throughout the globe, preventing the supposed goal of allowing everyone to share the fruits of prosperity.- Numerous fallacies were debunked by Bregman as to why people prefer to have borders instead. 1) terrorism, 2) criminal rates, 3) undermining social cohesion, 4) job competition, 5) decreasing wages due to immigrant labor, 6) immigrants are lazy, 7) immigrants will never go back to their home nations. However, all of these fallacious arguments are debunked. By opening borders, developing countries can rake in more cash that can be used to also curtail poverty for their citizenry. The pay gap between two workers with the same experience and skillset in two countries is jarring.
Conclusion
Lastly, if there is any takeaway from this book, it's that ideas change the world. During times of crisis where the status quo is challenged, it is the existence of alternative ideas, new ideas that can lay the groundwork for the new normal. This is a fascinating look at our current society, especially pertaining to our work/life balance. Rutger Bregman is a political historian and author, and his book was originally published in Europe, where it won literary acclaim. Years ago, many people predicted that with the advent of technology, humans would not have to work so hard, and machines would do the majority of the work. This would enable us to have much more leisure time. In fact, the opposite may have happened. Many more occupations have been created, including many jobs which are superfluous, and don’t contribute to the betterment of society. Numerous studies have proven that the less people work, the more productive their output. Overworked people don’t create any more, and tend to clog up creativity and ingenuity. Bregman includes a very interesting history on GDP, how it’s determined, what it measures, and what it leaves out. By relying on these statistics to gain insight on how our country is actually performing, can be misleading and inaccurate.I found Bregman’s argument for basic income exceptionally compelling. He defends that poor’s people number one issue is that they don’t have enough money, and by merely supplying them with adequate funds, a myriad of other issues simply disappear. When you consider the economic strain of the welfare state, and all the costs associated with dispensing the assistance, and all of the oversight, it’s actually more economically feasible to dole out cash, no strings attached. There have been numerous studies which have had much higher success rates. Fears about people squandering cash, or not managing the money well, are pretty much unfounded. People are so used to the welfare state, that it seems easier to continue the status quo. Included are lots of interesting studies, including some hosted by our own government, including Nixon’s administration. Bregman also argues that closed borders are one of the biggest discriminatory factors in our current world. Where you are born, not only dictate where you live, but where you can work and travel to and from. Your economic destiny is predetermined not by how hard you work, but by the economic conditions of your country, and its relationship to the rest of the world. This section has an interesting premise, but I felt it could be fleshed out more in another volume. This book poses a lot of questions about our current state of doing things, and if it’s really achieving the goals we set out to reach. Bregman argues there must be a better way of streamlining economic stimulus, making sure citizens are taken of, and making all of our lives more leisurely and enjoyable. I really found this book to be compelling and easily digestible. A modern day Thomas More for critical thinkers.

Well, this was massively disappointing. It bugs me no end when the title of a book itself screams false advertising. Utopia for Realists? More like Utopia for Optimists on Crack! Especially since, and I'm not kidding here, the author basically encourages the reader to be unrealistic in the very last paragraph! 🙄So first, a bit of context: I'm fairly on the "Left" to begin with, and am certainly open to the idea of UBI or a shorter work week. I'm in any case convinced that our growth, consumerism and work-obsessed neoliberal über-capitalist society needs a major overhaul if we want to ensure fairness, happiness, and oh, yeah, the freaking survival of our species on this planet in decently pleasant circumstances (the dire, existential threat of massive environmental destruction is, mostly, conveniently ignored by our author, which just baffled me). I'm even one of those who thinks perpetual economic growth needs to be questioned, and even dropped to a certain extent. The author does mention that a wee bit, but doesn't spend enough time on it, in my opinion... Largely because, and this was incredibly weird to me: despite proponing pretty "left-wing" ideas, he regularly, throughout the book, went out of his way to praise Capitalism, and neoliberalism. The lack of self-awareness and the amount of cognitive dissonance displayed by this guy was staggering. Truly staggering. I'm not saying he had to trash the concept of capitalism, not at all, but why was he so desperate to prop it up when it's so painfully obvious capitalism, or at least its excesses, is responsible for most of the societal ills he mentions in his book?! Like, what the hell was up with that? I'll also add that, while I'm by no means an economist, neither is he, clearly. I'll just go through some of the things that irked me: - Starts the book off with a Hobbesian narrative: the world was hell for everyone (or almost everyone, but the nuance here doesn't matter) before now. All our ancestors were stupider, more miserable, poorer, uglier (really?) than we are today. Oh fuckin' hell. I don't buy that. History is not a linear narrative (except, perhaps, technology-wise, and even that's actually debatable when you look at Antiquity vs. the Dark Ages), and you'd think that, as a supposed Historian, he'd know that. I'm not one of those people who thinks everything was better before either, by the way. Not at all. I think both statements are false. Some things were better at certain times than they are now. Other things, hell most other things, were worse, but not consistently worse either. It largely depends on time and place. And that's just for written History too. How the hell can you even compare the well-being/happiness of a 150000 year-old hunter-gatherer human to a modern one? It's a question that's literally impossible to answer, so I just cannot take an author who makes such black and white statements about the past and present that seriously. - Shoddy bibliography. Now, when you make grand claims about pretty complicated topics, I expect solid citations. Not, like, 50% of them coming from newspaper articles, opinion pieces or your own previous writing! Add to that the consistent lack of contextualisation; in so many instances it was ridiculous. I was like: "yes, but what does this actually mean in the context of your subject?" or "how can you even compare these things?" "How do you even define this, to make this statement/comparison?" And on and on it went. - The endless contradictions. Now, one or two I can understand: sometimes you don't know how to express nuance well, and it comes off as sounding like you're agreeing with two opposing statements. I get that, it happens to me too. But it just would not stop in this book. The author would say x on one page, then three pages letter would say the exact freaking opposite. Sometimes he'd even contradict statements supported by a citation, which was quite frankly hilarious (if not embarrassing). It would cross chapters too, undermining some of his arguments (this was especially relavant regarding his one chapter on open borders, which was by far the weakest of the three in my opinion, but then again I have more reservations about that idea, so I acknowledge bias might be at play). - The vagueness of some of his ideas, and the ultimate lack of direction in how to even apply them. Which is another reason why I find the title of the book to be misleading. This book is not a how to! It's, at best, a superficial introduction to the concepts of UBI, work-society restructuration and lighter borders/border abolition. I mean, sure, he introduces a couple of experiments that are being done, or more often, have been done in the past... and that's it. So, if it serves as a spark of inspiration for someone, cool I guess, but I was expecting something a bit more concrete and substantial. - The abysmal lack of awareness, or I guess just plain denial of the interconnectedness between capitalism (or at least, once again, capitalism in its current excessive/toxic form), sexism/misogyny (Patriarchy for short), racism/xenophobia (Colonialism for short) and, of course, environmental destruction on a massive scale...Oh, but wait, right, that doesn't really matter because we live in the Land of Plenty and all we need is just a few new ideas to push us forward because otherwise we stagnate in societal boredom, I guess? But at the same time, society has never been more unequal, and we're in the shit (only on a socio-economic level, mind you). 🙄 That's what I meant when I mentioned the constant contradicting going on in the book. I'll also add that he does, and I really hate myself for even putting it this way, sound like a smug, arrogant "white guy" at times. With overall good intentions, mind you. And that chapter on "open borders" I mentioned? Yeah, a shit-show. Epitomized every bit of criticism I just mentioned. With a good dollop of bad faith too. Applying statistics from one country to every other country (which, just, does not work, for so many reasons), using arguments he'd basically demolished in a previous chapter on automation and "robots are going to replace most jobs", ignoring a couple of elephants in the room (religion, and the threat to secular society or women's rights, for example), etc... Not to mention a lot of countries already have borders that aren't closed? So, is he actually advocating for abolishing borders entirely, or just asking countries not to close the borders they have? That wasn't clear at all. Personally, I'm more sympathetic to having regulated immigration than no immigration or unregulated immigration, so I guess I'm in favour of open borders? If that's what he actually meant?? Same with UBI. I'm in favour of the idea, but not if it means scrapping every other socialized system in place, such as universal healthcare. His position on that wasn't clear at all. He seemed in favour of scrapping a lot of elements of the "nanny" state, which I don't necessarily disagree with, but you can't just scrap everything either. UBI on its own, in the aggressive capitalist system we currently live in, wouldn't help much, as other commenters who agree with the concept, but not the way it's presented in this book, have pointed out. If this book can't appeal to someone who more or less agrees with its core premises, then there's no way in hell it will convince anyone who wasn't open to those ideas in the first place. I would not recommend this book to anyone honestly. But I'm open to better suggestions on those same subjects.

It would be all too easy for even the most romantic idealist - when observing our world riven by poverty, inequality, climate chaos and political extremism - to react with defeatism and despair. It is this self-defeating cynicism that the Dutch historian Rutger Bregman sets out to counteract in “Utopia for Realists: How we can build the Ideal World”. As fewer and fewer people believe a fairer, more just world can be created, and where we seem to have constructed societies “where optimism and pessimism have become synonymous with consumer confidence or the lack thereof”, “Utopia for Realists” is a commendable (if flawed) attempt to show another world is possible.Bregman spends much of this readable – although ultimately slight – volume sketching out the policy ideas that might comprise a new utopia. He argues against the predominance of GDP and GNP in economic theory and argues for the eradication of “bullshit jobs”. Having established how economic productivity and long hours do *not* go hand-in-hand with each other, he makes a passionate case for a shorter working week, viewing it as an antidote to everything from workplace stress and burnout, climate change, unemployment and family breakdown, through to declining levels of volunteering and involvement in civil society. He advocates higher taxes for higher earners, specifically as a way of moving citizens away from employment in the financial sector and as a method of getting “more people to do work that is useful”. Neither is Bregman afraid to propose policies that may appear unpopular in our current political climate; “Utopia for Realists” contains spirited defences of immigration and “a world without borders” as routes to economic fairness and poverty alleviation. As optimistic and upbeat as Rutger Bregman might be, the problem with “Utopia for Realists” is that it outlines a utopian vision without telling us how it might be turned into reality. Rutger Bregman is great at outlining why something like Universal Basic Income or giving free money to poor people are excellent ideas for society, but incredibly vague as to how you might get citizens to vote for them or pay for them. Similarly, ‘Open Borders’ is undoubtedly an ennobling concept but, as far-right populism seemingly sweeps the globe, how the hell do you get western electorates to sign up to it? It is not enough merely to describe what the promised land will look like; you also need to be able to build a bridge that people can cross to it.

It is unsurprising that Rutger's book, Utopia for Realists, has had such worldwide acclaim. It's clear, casual style makes it accessible to almost any reading level, and it's explanation of complex economic ideas through anecdote makes for an engaging and relatable read. It is what any thinker, who seeks to transform the world, should attempt to do. Long, rambling, inaccessible texts appear, which posture and serve only to convey the intellect of the author, are all too ubiquitous in the field of economics, philosophy, sociology, cultural studies, and beyond. Rutger's text, however, is a serious attempt to introduce ordinary people to transformative ideas. In this sense, it is a truly brilliant work.Because of this, and the avalanche of statistics that feature, Utopia for Realists is persuasive. The explanation of the 15-hour workweek and the universal basic income is successful in so far that it debunks all the criticisms of progressive economic ideas from the past, anticipating the critiques of ideologues who will no doubt hate the notion of a reduction in official working hours for the majority. The text draws on studies completed across the developed and developing worlds, and, Rutger shows, has positive outcomes. Autonomy of individuals - when money does not restrict them - creates wealth and prosperity, whether the universal basic income is implemented in North America, Europe, or Africa.What is less persuasive is the chapter on open borders. I struggled to find what it was precise that meant open borders were a good idea. Again, the anticipated criticisms were debunked, but the emphasis on why it would prove successful seemed to be glanced over. That it was relegated to the penultimate chapter of the book, when there was more than enough space in the middle section, seems to acknowledge this failing. More elaboration on this section would be useful if it is to convince the right-wing narratives that dominate debate in the UK and USA.Yet, the text itself, though some chapters seem superfluous, is excellent. It offers a real alternative that few other commentators - the 'armchair philosophers' Rutger calls them - have yet to provide. This is required reading for anyone who has had enough of the dreadful economic system of neoliberalism. It's not just for politicians or commentators to consume; it's a book for everyone, the dreamers who hope for a better world. Buy or steal a copy now.

The 'last chapter problem' afflicts all books that offer political and social analysis along with profound policy recommendations. Having outlined carefully what is wrong and what would fix it, the writer has little left to offer on how to actually implement these brilliant ideas. A common fallback is to invoke the need for 'political will' - which is always a euphemism for 'I have no idea how to do this'. Rutger Bregman almost gets around this in his epilogue by making a virtue out of 'impossiblism': the 1968 slogan 'be realistic, demand the impossible' is the actual political strategy. Bregman's policy goals (e.g. universal basic income; fifteen hour work week; tax capital not labour) are, in his view, on the right side of achievable, while offering a tantalizing and exciting social transformation. Bregman criticizes those he calls 'underdog socialists' on the Left - whose goal in life appears to be to deaden everyone else's expectations, and bore people to political death. Bregman makes convincing cases for the viability of all his proposals, using historical references and wonkish studies. My favorite section was his defense of the 'Speenhamland' system, a late 18th, early 19th century British attempt to set up a basic income system of family payments. Both Right and Left have derided Speenhamland as a failure, however Bregman argues that it was actually a great success, and it was brought down by false information and slander.Unlike a lot of 'policy wonk' writers, Bregman appreciates that how you get somewhere (i.e. by mass political activism) is as important as where you are going. Thus he argues for a radical politics that excites people - which makes a virtue out of 'impossible' goals. Bregman is an easy read, and it's easy to feel convinced by this book. Where do you go afterwards? Well you got to dream!

This book is not a Utopia for realists - it's a Utopia for daydreamers. None of the claims for UBI show financial feasibility. Most people would agree that giving money to the poor would help alleviate poverty - so that's not the question here. The real question is how would we go about executing it? Even with Elizabeth Warren's 2% wealth tax on the rich (which was considered extreme), she didn't have the budget to do half of the progressive agenda she wanted to do. Andrew Yang's UBI proposal was equal parts absurd and hilarious - he said to give Americans a bare minimum UBI he would only need a 10% VAT tax and a higher capital gains tax. Independent analysts claimed that even if Yang increased the VAT to 20% he would still be 25% short of his goal. How can a book about UBI completely overlook this? Where is the analysis that shows UBI is financially feasible? Here are a few other things that I noticed about the book that were completely off the mark.1.) He thinks that machine learning and robots are going to take all of the human jobs. This is a populist idea that's been around since the steam engine. This is how I feel about it: 	• The transition from labor-intensive jobs to knowledge-intensive jobs will continue to happen. And a lot of people will lose their current jobs - but there won't be a shortage of jobs. Those who refuse to change with the times will suffer, those who adapt will survive. There will always be work for humans because robots (however sophisticated we make them) will never truly understand human nature and what we need.	•  Contrary to popular opinion - this is a good thing. Labor-intensive jobs tend to be "slave-jobs" while jobs that require knowledge tend to promote psychological safety and individual liberties.	• Nowhere in the book does he have a critical analysis of jobs created due to technology vs. jobs lost due to technology. The reason is simple: he will have to admit to the fact that we are actually doing better jobs, and regardless of pockets of industries that have become obsolete, overall the number of occupations have increased.  2.) He argues that Education is not really a poverty trap - the real poverty trap according to him is "scarcity". He cites one review paper that concludes that financial literacy only explains 0.1% of the variance in financial behaviors to back this up - which I think is ridiculous.	• If you really want to read about poverty traps I recommend Abhijit Banerjee's "Poor Economics". In it, he shows that food scarcity is actually no longer a poverty trap in most of the world. Abhijeet also shows that education is really the biggest poverty trap there is - and we don't pay enough attention to it. Or at least think it's too much of a risk to invest that much of a long time in school.  Other poverty traps that we really need to focus on include health, city infrastructure and functional local governance (courts, banks, insurance etc).	 3.) Social mobility - he gets this wrong too. He says that there's no country on Earth where the American Dream is less likely to come try than in the US.	• Not true - America is not a monolith. The social mobility in US cities is equivalent to/or higher than European cities. The social mobility in rural areas are lower than European rural areas -  but not worse than developing countries.	 4.) "Bullshit jobs" and education - I don't even know where to start with this one. If public relations, human resources, and administrative jobs are "bullshit" - the only thing that is lacking is an organizational vision and leadership.	• He also thinks that by restructuring education, the job market will tag along. In a maybe tongue-in-the-cheek comment, he says we should teach budding Economists morals and philosophy. At this point, I really wanted to put down the book, but I read on.	• Everybody and their uncle have an opinion about Education and how it should change. I'm not against listening to any of these ideas: but the reality is there isn't going to be a solution that helps everyone. You can't lift the demand for artists, philosophers, historians (as he believes) from thin air. He seems to be wanting to use education for his own agenda - which is the one thing we should be worried about Education reform. 5.) The rant about GDP.  - I feel like he's just building a straw man here to beat up. We all know that GDP is a crude measure of production. No sane economist these days would use it as an absolute measure of growth. Instead it's only used to provide context and most people are careful to point out the caveats. 6.) Handing out money is better than microfinance? He comes to this conclusion in a very strange and delusional way.	•  First, he cites a study done by Esther Dufflo who he believes to say that microfinance doesn't help the poor. This is not true - that study says that business profits only increase for the 90th percentile of the people who get for-profit microfinance loans. But the study also says microfinance affects the structure of household consumption. Households invest in durable goods, restrict temptation goods and expenditures on festivals. For someone who just spent a whole chapter ranting about GDP, it's ironic that the author focuses on business profit as the only metric instead of these quality of life improvements.	• Second, he cites a completely different study that hands out money to the poor. I have no doubt that this helps the poor. But this is not a fair comparison to for-profit microfinance. For-profit microfinance is sustainable by itself while handing out money relies on donations or taxation - of course you would expect the poor to be better off with the latter. 7.) Banking and Neoliberalism -throughout the book there's narrative towards how neoliberalism started out and how it was orchestrated by a powerful few. And also how banking is this is evil institution. This is borderline conspiracy theory material. 	• The banking system is not inherently corrupt - there were a few ponzi schemes and bad players that took down the financial system while regulators were asleep. The real question is why did the regulators fail and how can we empower them? Not burn the whole system to the ground.	• This may also be an indication of the author's lack of understanding about the financial system. I don't know. Maybe that's why he never thought about writing about whether UBI is financially feasible? 	---------------------------------------- All-in-all this book delivers nothing it promised. It doesn't make the case for UBI. It doesn't tackle any of the important topics that expert economists are thinking about on eradicating poverty. Instead it comes off like a high-school essayist who had an assignment about "disruptive ideas for a better society"

Description: Universal basic income. A 15-hour workweek. Open borders. Does it sound too good to be true? One of Europe's leading young thinkers shows how we can build an ideal world today.After working all day at jobs we often dislike, we buy things we don't need. Rutger Bregman, a Dutch historian, reminds us it needn't be this way-and in some places it isn't.Rutger Bregman's TED Talk about universal basic income seemed impossibly radical when he delivered it in 2014. His April 2017 talk continues to make the provocative case, detailing the idea's 500-year history and even its brief success in a forgotten trial in Manitoba in the 1970s. Nearly a million views later, guaranteed basic income is being seriously considered by leading economists and government leaders the world over. It's just one of the many utopian ideas that Bregman proves is possible today.Utopia for Realists is one of those rare books that takes you by surprise and challenges what you think can happen. From a Canadian city that once completely eradicated poverty, to Richard Nixon's near implementation of a basic income for millions of Americans, Bregman takes us on a journey through history, and beyond the traditional left-right divides, as he champions ideas whose time have come. Every progressive milestone of civilization-from the end of slavery to the beginning of democracy-was once considered a utopian fantasy. Bregman's book, both challenging and bracing, demonstrates that new utopian ideas, like the elimination of poverty and the creation of the fifteen-hour workweek, can become a reality in our lifetime. Being unrealistic and unreasonable can in fact make the impossible inevitable, and it is the only way to build the ideal world.

His main topic is the Universal Basic Income."Free money: It’s a notion already proposed by some of history’s leading thinkers. Basic income: It’s an idea whose time has come."I've always been a fan of it, but the depth of his examination would put even the most hardline sceptic in its favour. For the first time in history, we are actually rich enough to finance a sizable basic income. We can get rid of the whole bureaucratic rigmarole designed to force assistance recipients into low-productivity jobs at any cost, and we can help finance the new simplified system by chucking the maze of tax credits and deductions, too. Any further necessary funds can be raised by taxing assets, waste, raw materials, and consumption."He nicely puts the irony of our quest for perpetual growth."Nevertheless, in the Land of Plenty we have come to the end of a long and historic voyage. For more than thirty years now, growth has hardly made us better off, and in some cases quite the reverse. If we want a higher quality of life, we will have to take the first step in search of other means, and alternative metrics. The idea that the GDP still serves as an accurate gauge of social welfare is one of the most widespread myths of our times. Even politicians who fight over everything else can always agree that the GDP must grow. Growth is good. It’s good for employment, it’s good for purchasing power, and it’s good for our government, giving it more to spend."And dispenses with the nobility and necessity fo work."When it comes to garbage collectors, though, it’s different. Any way you look at it, they do a job we can’t do without. And the harsh truth is that an increasing number of people do jobs that we can do just fine without. Were they to suddenly stop working the world wouldn’t get any poorer, uglier, or in any way worse. Take the slick Wall Street traders who line their pockets at the expense of another retirement fund. Take the shrewd lawyers who can draw a corporate lawsuit out until the end of days. Or take the brilliant ad writer who pens the slogan of the year and puts the competition right out of business. Instead of creating wealth, these jobs mostly just shift it around.""In other words, the fact that something is difficult does not automatically make it valuable. In recent decades those clever minds have concocted all manner of complex financial products that don’t create wealth, but destroy it. These products are, essentially, like a tax on the rest of the population. Who do you think is paying for all those custom-tailored suits, sprawling mansions, and luxury yachts? If bankers aren’t generating the underlying value themselves, then it has to come from somewhere – or someone – else. The government isn’t the only one redistributing wealth. The financial sector does it, too, but without a democratic mandate. The bottom line is that wealth can be concentrated somewhere, but that doesn’t also mean that’s where it’s being created. This is just as true for your former feudal landowner as it is for the current CEO of Goldman Sachs. The only difference is that bankers sometimes have a momentary lapse and imagine themselves the great creators of all this wealth. The lord who was proud to live off his peasants’ labor suffered no such delusions.""In Graeber’s analysis, innumerable people spend their entire working lives doing jobs they consider to be pointless, jobs like telemarketer, HR manager, social media strategist, PR advisor, and a whole host of administrative positions at hospitals, universities, and government offices. “Bullshit jobs,” Graeber calls them. They’re the jobs that even the people doing them admit are, in essence, superfluous.""In Graeber’s analysis, innumerable people spend their entire working lives doing jobs they consider to be pointless, jobs like telemarketer, HR manager, social media strategist, PR advisor, and a whole host of administrative positions at hospitals, universities, and government offices. “Bullshit jobs,” Graeber calls them. They’re the jobs that even the people doing them admit are, in essence, superfluous."And in talking about the redistribution of wealth and the possibilities, he looks at the reality of our race against the machines. And of course, the usual retardant to genuine progress - politicains."The problem is not the will of the people but the policital lack of imagination, ideological thinking and self preservation"Utopia is not a destination, but an ongoing journey."On the one hand, the world is still getting richer, safer, and healthier. Every day, more and more people are arriving in Cockaigne. That’s a huge triumph. On the other hand, it’s high time that we, the inhabitants of the Land of Plenty, staked out a new utopia. Let’s rehoist the sails. “Progress is the realisation of Utopias,” Oscar Wilde wrote many years ago. 24 A fifteen-hour workweek, universal basic income, and a world without borders … They’re all crazy dreams – but for how much longer?"And he finalises with actionable steps, actual policies and stuff we can actually fight for.Fantastic book, adding to the literature that shuns our political inaction and shines the light on a path forward.

Lots of interesting ideas and insights in here: the prevalence of useless jobs (and why it doesn't really matter if we're employed anyway), why we should be working less but don't (hint: consumerism), the case for a UBI and an altered taxation system focused more on capital than wages, why we should throw GDP in the bin and replace it with indexes that include happiness and wellbeing. Some parts are a bit left leaning and simplistic for me (eg universal open borders) but they are certainly food for thought in a time when lots of us are questioning the world's sociopolitical direction after this crisis passes

Bregman advocates for universal basic income, a shorter work week, and more open borders -- all sensible prescriptions for the realities of the modern world. He doesn't offer much in terms of how to actually achieve these worthy goals, but he provides lots of good policy commentary and argument. The more people start discussing policy ideas such as these, the more likely we are to eventually see them in mainstream dialogue. Bregman provides the talking points in an easy-to-read format.

1-10 Takeaways:1) Universal Basic Income is a good idea that almost became a reality in the US. In 1970, during Nixon's presidency (Republican), UBI passed in the House but not in the Senate only because Democrats wished that more money was provided. In many ways, UBI is a great compromise for Left and Right politics. For the Left, UBI offers an end to poverty, allows women to leave bad marriages and is much better than Welfare (Welfare is based off of learned helplessness and suspicion where applicants need to prove their helplessness all while State employees suspiciously vet the applicants and the applicant's neighbors distrust/look down on them). For the Right, UBI increases personal freedom to change jobs, go back to school, start your own business and inherently values the judgment of the individual to solve their own problems more than the "red tape" of State programs/employees. The UBI tests done in the US, Canada, India, etc. showed a decrease in government spending overtime. This is the kicker. If a government invests in its citizens on the front end (UBI), it avoids costs on the backend (incarceration, Welfare, funding government programs, lost human capital). 2) 15 hr. work week is a good idea. In 1930, Keynes predicted that in the year 2030 we would have 15 hour workweeks due to advances in technology. How has the increase in technology led to us working more rather than less? Bregman talks about bullshi*t or "shifter" jobs. Jobs where nothing of value is created but money is shifted around. A good test of whether a certain profession is a bullsh*t job is if those workers can go on strike and then nothing changes. This very thing happened in NYC in 1968 and Ireland in 1970. In NYC, the garbage collectors went on strike, trash began piling up, the mayor declared a state of emergency and then, in 9 days, all the garbagemen's demands were met. In Ireland, all the bankers went on strike. This froze much of Irelands cash. Sounds pretty dire, right? All the economists foresaw disaster; but, Ireland not only survived but the economy didn't worsen at all. After 6 months, all the bankers came back to work. The problem with bullsh*t jobs is that you have to be smart to have them. Some of the worlds best and brightest are occupying jobs like social media consultants, high frequency traders, etc.; but, if all the social media consultants didn't show up to work for an extended period of time, would we notice? The financial sector is 7x bigger than the agricultural sector of the US; but, we would feel the absence of farmers much more than bankers. The financial sector (like other sectors in the US) have become incredibly bloated where they are more shifting wealth around amongst themselves than adding value. (The financial sector isn't all bad. It contributes to our wealth, greases the wheels of other sectors, helps to spread risks and backs people with bright ideas.). A Harvard study of 12,000 professionals found that half of them believed their jobs to be superfluous. Another study showed that the more managers a position has, the less productive it is. Many intelligent people know that their job does not add value; but they are afraid to take a pay cut so as to work on something of value. There needs to be an increase in taxes and a crack down on tax havens to decrease the amount of intelligent people pursuing bullsh*t jobs. With the brightest pursuing jobs of value, the human race will experience enough abundance to work less. When we work less, our time will go towards hobbies that in turn stimulate the economy (Henry Ford reducing work hours so that his employees had time to go places/buy a Ford automobile). Many of the necessary jobs are challenging/not desirable (garbageman, etc.). If UBI exists, the people who pursue these challenging/essential jobs can bargain for better pay/work environments because they don't necessarily "need" the job). 3) Open boarders is a good idea. Common objections to open boarders: people won't go back, immigrants are lazy, immigrants are criminals/terrorists (benefit from government programs without adding value), immigrants will take our jobs. Responding to people won't go back, Bregman says: Before the US/Mexico boarder was heavily militarized, 58% of Mexicans came to the US but then went back. Now, with the militarized boarder, only 7% of Mexicans return. Mexicans are still coming into the United States illegally but now with the border, they don't leave. Responding to immigrants are lazy: a second tier citizen needs to be made where people can come to the country and work but they need to wait a certain amount of time/pay taxes before receiving full citizenship with all its benefits (UBI, etc.). Responding to immigrants are criminals/terrorists: In the US, as immigration has grown, the crime rate has been going down. For terrorism, studies show that visiting other countries increases empathy, different perspectives, etc.. People being able to travel between countries should diminish terroristic ideologies. Responding to immigrants will take our jobs: When women suddenly entered the work force in the 1970's, some men were worried about losing their "breadwinner" jobs. This is an inaccurate view of jobs. Jobs are not like musical chairs. More people in the workforce means more consumption which means more/new jobs. Open boarders would greatly reduce poverty. 60% of people's wealth is decided by the country they are born in. Two people with the same skill set will make dramatically different amounts just depending upon where they are born. Open boarders would greatly add to global wealth. Harvard economist, Lant Pritchett, predicts that allowing people to go from country to country, similar to how goods go from country to country, would increase global wealth by 63 trillion dollars. Crazy. 1-10 Questions: 1) Why is health insurance tied to jobs in America? This locks people into jobs that might not be best for them. If people new that they didn't have to give up their job + health insurance, they would be more free to change jobs, go back to school, start their own business, etc. Especially when studies show that America will save money on Universal Healthcare (https://www.theguardian.com/commentis...). (Is the concern that certain procedures will have a long wait time?)

This is a difficult review for me to write. I've spent many days thinking exactly what I would say about this book. My main issue is that I just don't agree with Bregman ideologically. With that being said, I don't want that to take away from the positive aspects of the book.First off, Bregman's motivation for writing this book is clear and inspiring. At times, his standpoints feel very opinionated, but overall his goal is to help readers feel like Utopia is possible. He tries to give people hope for the future. On the other hand, this book seems to assert that Utopia can only come out of more socialistic policies. Bregman cites some very convincing studies and provides well researched facts, but he makes very big assertions. He uses small case studies, to justify large-scale policies like universal basic income. I'm open to these ideas, but this book doesn't convince me. The book never really addresses why people might not support these ideas. Bregman doesn't offer or debunk most of the counter arguments.Overall, if you are interested in economics, politics, or public policy, this is a great read for anyone along the political spectrum. It definitely made me think long and hard about my standpoint, but it just didn't convince me in the end.

This is an entertaining airport lounge kind of read, filled with questions such as, why doesn't the world work better, and proof that the current mess it's in is, ultimately, unnecessary. Typically for a book of this kind is to present relatively counter-intuitive arguments supported by evidence from small scale case studies that have so far been buried under piles of governmental indifference. Homelessness would be less costly if we gave the homeless money. Work would be more productive if we reduced the time we spend on it. Performance-driven government by numbers obsessed with absurd targets and ever newer acronyms (GDP, Happiness index, Better life index, etc.) is not fit for humans. Basic income encourages industriousness. Poor people are not stupid, just overwhelmed with so many problems and economic worries that their decision making processes are impaired. And this in only the first half of the book. I'd recommend it, it's a light read, but does make you wonder, if you weren't already, why is the world in the mess it's in then?

If you're looking for inspiration and a "thinking out of the box" reading, this is a good book. If you are looking for concrete proposals to develop a universal basic income system, you could be disappointed.  The book raises arguments about a universal basic income, a shorter working week - and how these can help overcoming poverty and inequalities-, which make the reader think about other possibilities and how our vision about work/job is a recent social construction.One of the positive points in the book: the reference to some experiments done already. And the critical arguments concerning GDP, overcoming poverty, the new trend of "bullshit jobs", jobs in the digital era, social inequality...Some unsolved issues: how a country/government/estate could afford giving a basic income to everyone (specially with open borders); and the cultural particularities (specially in poorer countries) that could make a project like this one fail.

I recommend starting this book with an open mind, as Bregman departs from a lot of the older left-right divides. He hopes to cast our vision to a far horizon and try to get us thinking about things in a new light, according to what humankind's progress so far might allow for in the future. He assesses that despite the relative prosperity of a great deal of the world's population (and he gives a slew of figures to illustrate that), we maybe don't find a lot of meaning to our lives and require a new inspiration to animate us. While venturing into the topic of utopia, Bregman recognizes that real utopian ideas tend to lend themselves toward fanaticism, intolerance, violence, etc., so he aims merely to provide a looser vision that the typical more detailed utopian ideal.The first part of Bregman's utopian vision is free money. That is, a universal basic income (UBI). He makes a very compelling-sounding case for it, citing all manner of examples and studies. However, a close inspection of these reveal that most of them are means-tested, that is, aimed at only the poor, and therefore they are not "universal." This leaves it to question if everyone received a certain amount (let's say $3,000 per month), would not everyone's expectations and expenditures merely rise to that level, such that those without additional income would seem almost no better off than those without UBI today? Remember that Bregman, after insisting that even "poor" people in the West are well-off compared to wealthy people in the recent past or many people in less developed countries today, are still "poor" because the envy they have for those even richer than themselves and this causes significant anxiety for them--"it's all about relative poverty" (emphasis in original, p 65). Additionally, Bregman gives the impression of cherry-picking his evidence. For instance, he cites the example of 13 homeless people who received free money in England and how much they prospered. But how many of the homeless suffer from significant mental illness, and how might that affect a broader program? We don't learn from Bregman because he offers no evidence in this area. Certainly a simple UBI program would be less obnoxious and less expensive than a highly structured, regulated, well-staffed entitlement program with copious oversight. Restricting a basic income to only a means-tested basic income (not for all, but for the poor/needy), would undo some of the benefits of UBI's simplicity, but might help prevent the benefits being lost in the wash of money thrown at society, and also not involve giving away as much. Bregman does not really tackle the moral issue raised by Murray Rothbard, Robert Nozick, and the like--based on what argument may one person seize goods one person has worked for by force and just give them to another who has not? His arguments are chiefly pragmatic, and since Bregman here (and elsewhere) cherry picks and sometimes outright misrepresents his evidence, the reader is advised toward a bit of skepticism on the purely results-oriented elements.To focus a bit on that last point, Bregman claims to quote Frédéric Bastiat's tract about what is seen and what is unseen (the famous broken window story). While he starts the story accurately, he ends it by claiming Bastiat says what is unseen is "community service, clean air, free refills on the house." (p 103) In fact, Bastiat blew up the whole idea of consumerism that all of Bregman's economic arguments are premised on, that the development of capital is more important than spending for spending's sake. Which is precisely why we're not better off by bombing New York City every other year and rebuilding it, because what is not seen are the resources required to rebuild, while appearing to "stimulate" some aspects of the economy, are coming from other areas that would have been stimulated instead, and, at the end of the day, despite all that apparent "stimulation," we're only as well off as we were in the beginning, whereas had those resources gone to something new, we would have had what we already had plus something new besides. Which is why Liberty is the only philosophy to embrace peace as a means toward greater prosperity.Bregman goes on from UBI toward a shorter work week, specifically, a 15-hour week. He actually alleges that "medieval people were probably closer to achieving the contended idleness of the Land of Plenty than we are today." (p 138). Of course they were, and it's precisely why their lives were so primitive and short, as well, a fact Bregman documents in his first chapter. Bregman makes it sound like everyone is eager to work less, citing (selectively) study after study and survey after survey. Yet, in the end, he calls for a recourse to government violence to enforce his idea, "There is hardly a politician around still willing to endorse it." (p 146) Prosperous people are certainly under no obligation to work 40 or more hours a week if they don't wish to, and I know some who don't. But that so many do--why did Bill Gates keep going to work day after day for so long?--is stronger testimony than any studies or surveys Bregman might cite. And if the idea of a 15-hour work week is so terrific, why do we have to point the government's gun at everyone's head to enforce it?More practically, think about what such a law would do. Bregman is a writer. So that means he would not only be forbidden from writing for more than 15 hours a week, but he could not think about his writing, do research for his writing, talk about his writing, meet with readers, sell his product, for more than 15 hours a week, combining all those tasks. How would we enforce it? With a Harrison Bergeron-style buzzer interrupting Bregman's thoughts for all but 15 hours a week? Bregman is correct that we could probably live as good a life as we presently do on quite a bit less work every week. But we would be treading water. Forget about a COVID-19 vaccine, a cure for cancer or AIDS or the common cold, flying cars, reduced pollution, improved agricultural methods, etc. Forget about progress. And if people are so stressed out from just relative inequality, even if they are far from absolute poverty, they will become more stressed when they realize they are prohibited from hustling to improve their position.Bregman also takes aim at "bullshit" jobs, many of which are jobs he just doesn't understand in terms of value-added. Why did people line up to bail out banks with their hard-earned incomes back in 2008 if nobody needs a bank and they don't add value? One of the "facts" Bregman cites to prove his contention against the financial sector is that "For every dollar a bank earns, an estimated equivalent of 60 cents is destroyed elsewhere in the economic chain." (p 169) This doesn't even pass the third-grader test. Given both the volume of dollars that pass through banks and the frequency with which they do, if this were true, we'd be living in the Stone Age already. I would agree with Bregman that there are a number of people who individually feel their jobs are bullshit, and I would take those individuals at their word. No doubt such things exist (I've seen some too), but much of what Bregman lumps into that category merely reveals his own ignorance about what some people do.Bregman suggests open borders. I will try not to tell him that puts him in the camp of real Liberals like that sneaky Friedrich Hayek (no, not anti-Liberal "liberal" Progressives, but real Liberals in favor of Freedom and Liberty). He cites the many benefits of doing so. While some of his figures might be suspect (especially since he has shown elsewhere a mighty flexibility in both picking and quoting facts), in fact it is hard to argue that open borders do anything but benefit everyone on the net. However, if combined with other things like raising taxes and providing free handouts, those with the goods would leave the high-tax areas, and those without would flock to them, so it turns out Liberty is pretty much a package deal. All of it (or at least most of it) or the pieces Bregman would cafeteria-style select might well undo to more Statist elements selected.Speaking of Liberalism, Bregman tries to crucify it, especially by citing economic crises. He completely ignores the amount and level of government intervention in each of them, as well as the contribution to economic trouble made by well-meaning interventions after the fact. For instance, he cites the 2008 crisis and says "one free-market dogma after another crashed and burned." (p 241) He should try reading Dick Morris' predictions prior to the crisis describing the role of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in creating the housing crisis and predicting its outcome (accurately). The fact that Bregman's own first chapter is pretty much a vindication of the practical benefits of Freedom, he is really only left with complaining that Freedom does not leave anyone feeling fulfilled and motivated (I would agree), and its natural outcomes (such as income inequality) leave people feeling anxious, no matter how much better off they are even being at the bottom of a rising pile. Maybe try reading Jonah Goldberg's Suicide of the West: How the Rebirth of Tribalism, Populism, Nationalism, and Identity Politics Is Destroying American Democracy for a different take on both the reasons for today's malaise and what to do about it.Make no mistake, Bregman identifies real problems in the world today. His writing style is fluid and entertaining, he makes his subject accessible to all. Some of his observations and even one-liners are as penetrating as they are entertaining. He turns out to sometimes be a little too glib, on close inspection... So when it comes time for real solutions, I would keep looking, but anyway, the book is worth reading.

Really interesting. At the beginning I thought that maybe I wouldn't be as interested in the book as I previously had thought, because I wasn't very agree with some of the ideas from the first chapter, but the truth is that in the rest of the book I've shared many of the opinions defended by the author.His proposals talking about working less hours, productivity, economy, poverty, politics, education, etc., are substantiated, as well as the critics he makes about the underdog socialism that is destroying itself... I save for myself a quote from this book: "Don't let anyone tell you what's what. If we want to change the world, we need to be unrealistic, unreasonable, and impossible. Remember: those who called for the abolition of slavery, for suffrage for women, and for same-sex marriage were also once branded lunatics. Until history proved them right".

I thought this was a very useful book, not necessarily for the factual content (although that's also interesting!) or for the arguments for things like universal basic income or open borders. The idea of needing 'utopian' goals to orient our work, or the need for radical ideas to have any kind of change or reflection of our current paradigm, was super motivating for me and also very useful to how I look at the work and role of governments. A lot of public documents and public ethics talk about the role of government to work for improving the "public interest". We can't know what that is without big ideas that look beyond incrementalism. Step-by-step planning is necessary in complex systems but we need forward looking and ideas that change the way things are done for incremental steps to have any meaning.

Such a great book!Not only was it an endlessly intriguing read, it also challenged my own views on the welfare system and on the division of labor (among other things).It’s also one of the first books I’ve read in a while that, while reading, I kept a note going in my phone for anything mentioned that I wanted to look further into. The research completed was thorough and expansive, andI’m looking forward to delving further into it.It’s also, thankfully, not an overt call to action. The title had me wondering if this would come off as preachy, but aside from a few subtle nudges in the body of the novel and an elbow dig in the epilogue, it was thankfully free of the proselytising I was dreading. Highly recommend. It’s a good’un.

It's a decent bit of mainstreaming of viable but oft-ridiculed paths to a more "ideal" society. Reads like an inverted Freakonomics, where instead of a "it's just the way things are, lol sorry!" message it adopts the "TIL stuff can be better!". The problem boils down to tone. It's a great book for giving facts, but there doesn't seem to be any underlying criticism of the current mindset beyond "oh, we were wrong, silly us!". It plays as flippant at worst and toothless at best, and that can be really incongruous when you're discussing vast income inequality or life expectancy. It's more likely than most to convince others, but if you're already immersed in these topics then I wouldn't expect much benefit from it.

Billionaires with their blood money, and you can have it as long as you say what they want you to say.ME: WTF, I love UBI now.

I read this at the start of the year and already feel like I need to go back and reread. Rutger Bregman touches on a number of topics that have become a political focus with covid-19. Universal Basic Income (and a brief look at the countries that have already experimented with it), what does it mean to build (or rebuild) a society, what role should the economy play in the world and what happens when we let society serve the economy (instead of the economy serving society).The first time I read this I found a lot of the ideas interesting but fairly abstract. Now it's starting to look like necessary reading for anyone with an interest in the potential for a new, post-covid world.

"Progress is the realization of Utopias" Oscar WildeThis was truly eye opening to me. I loved the very positive attitude of the author concerning the times we live in. I also liked that he included studies that didn't fit his own perspective to give you a better perspective of issues. And I loved that he backed everything up with countless studies, which I plan to investigate in the future. This book must have been a monstrosity to put together, yet it was written in a very reader friendly way. I can highly recommend this book!

I was expecting a regurgitation of the arguments I've heard time and time again from Andrew Yang and other contemporary proponents of UBI. This book actually provides a broader scope, by exploring the history and philosophy behind these 'utopian' ideas in a kinda messy but very easily readable way. Granted, the writer does not offer concrete implementation strategies, but that was not the point of the book. For me, it was nothing more than an intriguing exploration of how historical concepts and ideas inform a new vision for the future.

The book is an excellent reminder that the status quo isn't the inevitable result of progress and that today, perhaps more than ever, we need big ideas to choose a different path for the future. Using history and research, the author shows that universal basic income and a shorter work week (among other "utopias") are far from new or unfeasible ideas. Changing the world and redefining what we value as a society, requires us to be "unrealistic, unreasonable, and impossible" – just like those before us who fought for women rights, same-sex marriage, or to end slavery.

I loved this book, right down to the feel of the cover and the pages in my hands, the weight of it. But I did find it helpful to remember that I naturally wouldn't agree with all of it. (Bergman is a neoliberal, just from a more left leaning country than mine.)The research in this was to the point but also interesting ans insightful, and nothing was wasted or overbearing. Ideas were explained thoroughly but accessibly; this really isn't a book for economists or academics. I really would recommend this book to anybody.

Fulfilling to read abt Utopia - positive and affirmative. Helpful for navigating political negativity. Kinda wanted to give it 3 stars but realised I would be doing so mainly on the basis that it isn't radical enough - but had to keep in mind the title of the book. Good overview of universal basic income, shorter workweek and open borders. Bit western centric. Missed opportunity to talk about post-genderism.

3.5 When I'm not on the app, I'll link to the review that captured a lot of my feelings about this book. There are a lot of good data, but some of his conclusions don't go far enough. Universal basic income is just a stipend for landlords without rent control and right to housing for instance. He hits housing a little bit doesn't connect it all. He also lacks almost any disability analysis or that of ageing. There's a lot of meritocracy stuff and neoliberalism.

An optimistic outlook on our society and world has to include 1) universal income to combat the rise of the useless class, 2) less time spent in the treadmill to improve productivity and creativity, and 3) freedom of human movement to harness and maximize the wealth creation and eradicate poverty. Rutger Bregman includes all of this and more in this entertaining and uplifting book on how to work to achieve Utopia.

Interesting book written by someone who is unafraid (and unashamed) to dream big, and who thinks outside the box. If you don't agree with his findings, perhaps you will be shaken into a new thought process! That said, it did get a bit repetitive at times; it looks like it's a series of essays molded into one book.

Really interesting book if you feel the world has collectively lost any sense of vision for the future. Bregman doesn't step out how to make a better future, but postulates on the possibilities of a world where we embrace concepts like Universal Basic Income, open borders and a shorter working week. The book is well-researched and feels hopeful.
This book is basically a lovefest for anyone who dares to dream of a better world. I left this read feeling inspired, as if an external creative impulse has been gifted to me. I couldn't put it down.
